text: A college counselor stands at the Podium lecturing the hi school seniors about their future.

... For those of you going on to college next year, the chance of finding a good job will actually decrease by the time you graduate. Entry level jobs will drop from thirty-one to twenty-six percent, and the median income for those jobs will go down as well ... There is some rustling in the audience.

Obviously, my friends, it's a competitive world and good grades are your only ticket through. By the year Two Thousand  ... INT. HIGH SCHOOL. HEALTH CLASS. A different teacher lectures a different class of student
... The chance of contracting HIV from a promiscuous lifestyle will climb to one in one hundred and fifty. The odds of dying in an auto accident are only one in twenty-five hundred. (beat)
Now this marks a drastic increase ... INT. HIGH SCHOOL. SCIENCE CLASS. Same angle. Different teacher.

... From just four years ago when ozone depletion was at ten percent of its current level. By the time you are twenty years old, average global temperature will have risen two and a half degrees. Even a shift of one degree can cause such catastrophic consequences as typhoons, floods, widespread drought and famine. REVERSE ANGLE. STUDENTS. They stare back in stunned silence. One of them, DAVID WAGNER, sits in the front row with a pencil in his mouth. Nobody moves ...
(chipper classroom tone)
Okay. Who can tell me what famine is?

Birds are chirping. The sun is shining. All the hedges ar neatly pruned and the lawns are perfectly manicured. A sw stillness hangs over the SUBURBAN STREET, which is bathed beautiful BLACK AND WHITE.

Honey, I'm home. SUBURBAN HOME. GEORGE PARKER enters the front door and hangs his hat on coatrack. He sets his briefcase down and moves into the f with a huge smile on his face. It's a frozen smile that doesn't seem to be affected by too much in particular--li tour guide at Disneyland.

Hello darling. WIDER. MRS. GEORGE PARKER (BETTY) enters, untying the back of he apron. She is a vision of '50s beauty with a thin figure concrete hair. Betty crosses to her husband and hands him fresh martini. She kisses him on the cheek.
How was your day?
Oh, swell. You know, Mr. Connel said that if things keep going the way they are, I might be seeing that promotion sooner than I thought.
Oh darling that's wonderful! (an adoring gaze)
I always knew you could do it. WAGNER LIVING ROOM. NIGHT.

DAVID WAGNER sits on his couch watching this entire actio a sleek new Sony T.V. He stares riveted at the set with a smile on his face. David wears black shoes, black pants, black t-shirt and a black baseball cap, not a nerd exactl ... He reaches next to him into a huge bag of Doritos, ne taking his eyes off the show.
(on T.V.)
Hey, Pumpkin! What's that smell? (sniffing)
Is that your meat loaf?
(by rote)
"It might be ..."
(shy smile)
It might be. He leans over and kisses her--again on the cheek.

Oh Pumpkin! You sure know the way to this man's heart. There is a loud and inappropriate LAUGH TRACK. David smil wider and is just about to reach for more corn chips, whe his real MOTHER'S VOICE rings out from the other room.
... Bullshit Barry, that wasn't the deal INT. KITCHEN. David's mom paces the room with the phone in her hand. Between the plastic surgery and the make-up it's hard to her age.
No--you have custody the first weekend of every month and this is the first weekend ... (pause)
I don't care if yesterday was the thirtieth, this is still the first weekend. INT. LIVING ROOM. Her words drift in from the kitchen while David stares at show.
No I can't bail you out, I'm supposed to go to La Costa ... (beat)
Well if I want to get a mud bath, that's really my business, isn't it? He reaches out and TURNS UP THE SOUND. PLEASANTVILLE play an unnaturally high volume.
(on T.V.)
Hey. Where are those kids?
(reciting--a little louder)
"Right behind you father."
(on T.V.)
Right behind you father.
The Parkers' son and daughter (BUD AND MARY SUE) enter th foyer together. Mary Sue wears her hair in a pony tail. B has on a Letterman's sweater.
Mother ... Father ... Bud has a little surprise for you.
What's that Bud? Bud hesitates for a moment, then folds up a shiny blue ribbon.
First prize at the science fair. There were lots of swell projects--guess mine was just the "swellest".
Darling that's wonderful. Except there's no such word as "swellest".

Well gee whizz, Mom. lt wasn't the "English" fair. There is another jarring LAUGH TRACK. CLOSE UP. DAVID. He smiles right along with it. David stares transfixed at set despite the continuing conversation in the other room
Well sure they can stay by themselves, Barry, but that's not the point. You said you'd take them. (beat)
Well fine--they'll stay by themselves then.
(quietly)
What's a mother to do?
(on T.V.)
Oh--what's a mother to do? CLOSE UP. DAVID. He grabs another handful of Doritos staring at the T.V ..

A cacophony of modem life. Beepers and nose rings--blue h and tattoos. Dissonant boom boxes compete with one anothe The hormones are running crazy. SCHOOL COURTYARD. lt is a large open area, alive at lunchtime. Groups of ki hang out together, divided by their various cliques. The music pounds in the background. CLOSE UP. DAVID. He stands at one end of the courtyard beside a chain link fence. Beads of sweat form on David's forehead as he spea to someone in front of him.
Hi. I mean ... (pause)
... Hi. REVERSE ANGLE. A very pretty blonde girl smiles back at him. It's a warm welcoming smile. CLOSE UP. DAVID.
Look. You probably don't think I should be asking you this. I mean--not knowing you well and all ... REVERSE ANGLE. GIRL. She smiles wider at him, inviting him to continue. CLOSE UP. DAVID.
(pause ...)
I mean I know you--everybody knows you ... I just don't know you ... technically. REVERSE ANGLE. GIRL. She nods at him ... CLOSE UP. DAVID.
Well--I was just wondering--'cause I see you all the time in Algebra and I heard you humming that Van Halen song and I really like that song too ... (pause)

Anyhow, I don't know what you're doing this weekend but my Mom's leaving town and she said I could use her car so ... REVERSE ANGLE. GIRL. She positively beams. The girl flicks her blonde hair and stares back at him adoringly. CLOSE UP. DAVID. Instead of smiling back, David just stares, then looks at ground. WIDE ANGLE. SCHOOLYARD. For the first time WE SEE THAT SHE WASN'T TALKING TO HIM. David stands a good hundred yards across the schoolyard, rehearsing this speech while the young woman stands face face with a much cooler boy. He has a cell phone and a ve hip haircut. ANGLE. DAVID. David watches as the girl throws her arm around the boy's waist and heads out of the playground ...

David and his friends are all gathered around the plastic picnic tables and vending machines that form the luncheon court. The chess club meets at one end and there are some teachers at the other. All the cool kids are on the other side of the fence but David and his friends eat lunch at same table every day.
Okay, whose window did Bud break when he was playing with his father's golf clubs?
Easy. Mr. Jenkins. What JOB did Mr. Jenkins have? Howard looks at him, puzzled.
Salesman. What did Bud and Mary Sue name the cat they found in the gutter?
Scout?
Marmalade. They all nod--and murmur with admiration.
Okay--here's one: Why did their parents come home early from their weekend at the lake? Everybody thinks. Nobody knows.
'Cause Bud didn't answer the phone and they were worried about him. It's quiet for a beat.
You're unbelievable. You'll win this thing for sure. When is it on?
Marathon starts at 6:30. Contest's tomorrow at noon.
(weighing it)
A thousand dollars ... And it's on all night?
Of course it is Howard. That's why they call it a Marathon.

head_text.subj: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE FENCE.

text: David's sister, Jennifer, hangs out with her friends in t parking lot. All the girls are dressed in the exact same uniform: Blue jeans, beeper on the belt, white V-neck T shirt, car keys in their hand. (Even the girls WITHOUT a hold car keys in their hand). Jennifer is by far the prettiest and, thus, is the leader of the group. They all look toward the Luncheon Court where David and his friend are hanging out.
Omigod, it's so mortifying, being related to him. I can't believe you're like--
Only on my parent's side.
I know, but you're like ... twins and stuff. (beat)

You must be from like, the cool side of the uterus. A group of VERY HIP boys strut through the parking lot. T bop up and down with the self-confidence of all cool sixt year olds. The girls freeze when they see them.
Omigod, omigod--here they come.
Don't do anything. Just don't like--do anything ...
(cooly)

Hi Mark. DIFFERENT ANGLE. He pauses then looks over at her. Jennifer slides sinuous off the fender of the car, flicking her hair like a young racehorse. She has a perfect 16 year old body and the who parking lot knows it. Mark heads over to her, followed by lackies. The two groups meet at the tail-gate of the Niss Pathfinder like a small summit conference.
(to Jennifer)
Hey.
(right back)
Hey. Beat ...
(to Jennifer's lackies)
Hey.
(back to them)
Hey.
Saw you at the mall yesterday.
Yeah ... Saw you too. Everyone nods for a moment or two. No one says anything.
So you watching Pearl Jam on MTV tonight?
Yeah. (beat)
Jennifer pauses, weighing the next statement.
My mom'll be out of town. Kimmy and Christin positively GASP while Mark's Lackeys mumble and glance around. The import of the thing isn't l on anybody. Mark bobs up and down a little faster.
So uh ... Maybe we could uh ...
(smiling)
Cool.
(nodding faster)
Cool.
Cool. Everybody bobs and shuffles for  beat, when Mark nods, summoning his flock.

lt is a south-westem version of "Leave it to Beaver." The uniformity of Suburbia has been washed in earth tones. Th is a red tile roof gracing every home. All the houses hav the same anemic palm tree. It's a urban planner's version hell.

... I know, I know--He's just like so FINE ... I'm still like: "Omigod." INT. WAGNER HOME. lt is just as sleek and impersonal as before. Maybe more at night. Jennifer crosses through the living room with t cordless phone attached to her ear.
It was amazing, Daph ... I'm like: "Well my Mom'll be out of town." And he's like "Well then, maybe we could-- you know ..." And I'm like "Yeah, sure." And he's like "Well, cool." (beat)
I know, he's just so smart. (pause ...)
I don't know. Maybe that black thing I just got. (pause ...)
It is not slutty, Daph, it's cute. (pause ... )
Well, "hello?" He's not coming  over here to study ... (beat)

I know. Well I'm jealous of you too sometimes. INT. DAVID'S BEDROOM. lt is studious and academic--not joyless, but not colorfu either. David stands at his bedroom window, staring outsi with a cordless phone in his hand.
... He's not homeless Howard, they just don't say where he lives. (pause ...)
Well it's a silly question. (pause ...)
Because nobody's homeless in Pleasantville. REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. His mother loads the final Louis Vuitton bag into her Mercedes.
... because that's just not what it's like. She fires up the car and pulls out of the driveway...

Listen Howard--it's almost six-thirty. I gotta go. INT. WAGNER LIVING ROOM. The huge black TV sits like a monolith in the middle of t room. All at once David comes bounding down the stairs ma a B-Iine for the couch. Jennifer enters just as quickly f the other direction, fiddling with her clothes. DIFFERENT ANGLE. They hit the coffee table and reach for the remote contro exactly the same moment. Both of them freeze then look up each other in shock.
(stunned)
What are you doing?
What are you doing? Neither one moves. They clutch the remote together.
David, cut it out. Mark Davis is gonna like be here in five minutes.
Well great. The Pleasantville Marathon starts at six thirty.
Pleasantville Marathon?
(almost reverently)
Yeah. Every episode ever.
(getting hysterical)
Omigod, I don't be-lieeeeve this! He's gonna like beeeee here!
Weil great. You can watch TV upstairs.
Upstairs! Up-staiiirs! There isn't any

Jennifer gets panicked and yanks at the remote. David yan back and before they know it, the remote goes flying out their hands, CRASHING onto the hardwood floor. lt smashes into a million tiny pieces.
(breathless)
Oh my God ... (sinking to his knees/ scooping up the remains)
Oh my God ...
David, stop stressing, you can like-- turn it on normally ...
No you can't, Jen! It's a new TV. It doesn't work without a remote. David cradles the pieces like a fallen comrade, when the DOORBELL RINGS behind him.

Oh my God! He's here! Jennifer sweeps some of the pieces frantically under the and tries to adjust her outfit on the way to the door. Da just stares in shock at the shattered plastic. Jennifer reaches the front door and wets her lips. She fluffs her quickly, sticks out her chest then swings it open. DIFFERENT ANGLE. FRONT DOOR. Jennifer steps forward with her sexiest smile, but it isn Mark Davis on the other side. DICK VAN DYKE STANDS ACROSS THRESHOLD IN A TV REPAIRMAN'S OUTFIT. Jennifer looks at h puzzled. He steps forward, flashing her a chipper grin, toolbox in hand.
TV repair.
(beat)
TV repair?
Yeah. TV busted?
(pause ...)
Yeah ...
(smiling wider)

Well here I am. REVERSE ANGLE. DAVID'S POV. He glances out the front door toward a weird VAN parked a the curb. It says TV REPAIR on the side but looks like something from a medicine show. The antenna on top resemb a weather vane and the mural beneath it depicts a happy family from the 1950s, gathered around their TV set. Ever wears a smile, including the dog. The hand-painted motto reads "Rob's TV Repair--WE'LL FIX YOU FOR GOOD." INT. LIVING ROOM. David looks back at Dick Van Dyke who smiles at him, then crosses to the living room STEPPING NIMBLY AROUND THE OTTOMAN. He heads toward the TV.
(seeing the smashed remote)
Holy cow. Look at that. Had a little disaster didn't ya fella.
Yeah ... Sort of ...
(setting down the toolbox)

We'll get you fixed up in no time. He pops the top of the tool box while Jennifer and David stare. It's a strange looking box with the same happy fam painted on the side. Dick Van Dyke pulls out another remo
I know how I'd feel if mine went out. Almost like losing a friend.
(tentatively)
You know, we didn't call any TV repair.
Well that makes it a lucky day for both of us, hunh? Jennifer shuts the door and crosses down toward the livin room.
You think you could do this like soon? It's almost six thirty.
What's the rush?
(cutting her off)

The Pleasantville Marathon starts at six thirty. At that moment there is a huge FORK OF LIGHTNING and a booming CLAP OF THUNDER. It literally rattles the walls o the house as Dick Van Dyke turns toward David.
Pleasantville? David recoils slightly. Dick Van Dyke flashes him a smile
Gosh, I loved that show. Watched it for years.
That's not the reason. I've got a date at six thirty.
(ignoring her/ leaning closer to David)
Hey--who did Muff in take to the masquerade ball when her date came down with the measles?
(stunned)
... Her father.
Right. And how did she dress him?
(still staring)
... Like Prince Charming.
(studying David/ nodding)
Nice ... Nice ...
Um--hello? I've got like a social emergency here.
(ignoring her)
Remember the one where Bud lost his cousin when he was s'posed to be watching him?
Yeah ...
What department store did they go to?
McIntire's.
McGinty's.
No. McIntire's. Remember: (sings)
"For the very best in men's attire, Head right down to McIntire's."
(stunned)
That's right. He stares at David, speechless, for a moment, then smiles fondly and reaches beside him for his tool kit.
Say--why don't you take this remote instead. It's got a little more "Ooomph" in it.
Ooomph?
Sure. Big beautiful set like this--you want something that'll put you right in the show.
(quickly)

We'll take it. CLOSER. He flashes them a big smile and holds out a weird looking contraption that seems more primitive than space age. It' strange combination of an early transistor radio and Flas Gordon ray gun. Dick Van Dyke extends it with pride, whil Jennifer and David stare at him warily ...
(beat)
How much does it cost?
Oh--couldn't charge you for something like that. It's free.
Free?
Oh sure. Big fan like yourself. It's the least I could do. There is a SECOND CLAP OF THUNDER even louder than the fi The house rattles for a moment then is quiet.
Well, I better get going. Your show's almost on, and ... (smiling at Jennifer)

It's almost time for your date. He places the remote control gingerly on the coffee table smiles at them. Dick starts across the living room when h suddenly catches his foot on the leg of the ottoman and tumbles end over end. He rolls on the carpet, executes a perfect somersault and comes right back to a standing position. David and Jennifer stare at him stunned when he looks back at them and smiles.
(grinning)

Take care now. There is another flash of lightning as he reaches for the doorknob. David and Jennifer look at one another while th front door shuts with a THUD. It's quiet for a second or before there is another CLAP OF THUNDER. David cocks his head. DIFFERENT ANGLE. David glances down at the strange contraption sitting on coffee table. It looks a little scary. Slowly, very slowy reaches down and touches it. Nothing seems to happen so h picks it up. CLOSER. David points the remote toward the TV set with an apprehensive look on his face. He winces a little, then pushes one of the buttons. DIFFERENT ANGLE. The TV set turns on. Oprah's face fills the screen as an angry housewife screams at a transvestite!
Hunh. It ail seems normal as he pushes another button. This tim the channel changes.
(relaxing)
Great. He continues to press the button, flipping through the channels. Jennifer sees that everything is fine and reach for the remote.
Lemme see that.
No way. He continues to flip through the channels, coming to rest the Pleasantville Marathon. BUD'S VOICE fills the room.
(on TV)
Gee whizz, Mary Sue--why can't I borrow your transistor radio?
(on TV)
I promised Betty Jane she could use it over the weekend.

Bud and Mary Sue clutch either end of a small transistor radio. They seem to be in the EXACT SAME POSITION as Davi and Jennifer, who are struggling over the remote control. ANGLE. DAVID AND JENNIFER. She tugs the remote while David yanks in the other direct
Do you mind. This is like the most important moment of my whole life.
Forget it Jen, I've waited a year for this.
(on TV)
"But I told Mr. Miller I'd bring a transistor in to electric shop."
(on TV)
"And I told Betty Jean she could have it for the picnic with Roy."
(yanking at it)
God, David. Just give it to me!
(yanking it back)
Get lost!

YOU get lost! WIDER. LIVING ROOM. She tugs at the remote trying to wrestle it out of his ha David pulls in the opposite direction as they POINT IT DIRECTLY TOWARD THE TV. DIFFERENT ANGLE. SPECIAL EFFECT. A huge white light emanates from the contraption, like th own atomic blast wave. The entire room is filled with a BLINDING AURA for a second or two, before it actually get sucked into the TV. WIDE ANGLE. LIVING ROOM. It is suddenly empty--illuminated only by the soft glow o the picture tube. David and Jennifer are nowhere in sight INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. (PLEASANTVILLE) DAY. David and Jennifer are standing in the middle of the 1950 living room, dressed in Bud and Mary Sue's clothing. They still clutch the remote control in the exact same positio that was occupied by their fictional counterparts. David Jennifer glance at one another, then look horrified aroun the room. THE WORLD HAS TURNED TO BLACK AND WHITE...
(a whisper)
Oh my God.
What happened?
I'm not sure.
George Parker (Bud and Mary Sue's father) enters from the landing whistling a happy tune. He's dressed in a gray su with a gray shirt, and a dark gray tie with little gray d
(as if to his own children)
Hi Sport, hi Muffin ... Better get a move on, you're gonna be late for school. He continues to cross through the living room whistling i the kitchen ...
(desperately)
What did you do?
I don't know.
(examining her black and white skin)

Uchh! Look at me?! I'm like so ... pasty! He glances down at the remote control that sits lifeless his hand. David frantically presses the buttons but nothi happens. All at once, there is a voice behind them.

Psst! Over here. DIFFERENT ANGLE. They whirl around to see DICK VAN DYKE'S FACE smiling at from the TV set in the comer. It's an old '50s set with a round picture tube. They run over to him as he smiles. Hi face is the only color in the room.
(beaming)
Told you it was your lucky day. Bet you thought I was just a fan or something.
What happened?
A miracle. They stare stunned at the TV set.

... See, every time I thought I'd found someone they'd turn out to disappoint me. They'd know the early episodes, but they wouldn't know the later ones ... They'd know all about Muffin but they wouldn't know about Bud ...
(to the TV set)
What the hell's going on!
Shh! Can't talk like that now. You're in ... (smiles)
You know ... David glances around at his black and white surroundings. "mother's" voice rings out from the kitchen.
Bud. Mary Sue ... Breakfast is on the table.
We're in Pleasantville?
(grinning)
Dream come true, hunh?
(panicking)
This isn't funny! I happen to have a very important date in like five minutes!
Well, you don't have to worry about that anymore.

All at once the scene on the TV changes and Dick Van Dyke picture gives way to a WIDE ANGLE SHOT of the WAGNER HOUS Mark Davis is standing at the front door, BANGING on the brass knocker. He checks his watch, shifts restlessly for moment or two, then turns and heads down the flagstone wa never looking back.
(under his breath)
... Bitch.

location: PARKER LIVING ROOM., (BLACK AND WHITE AGAIN)

text: Jennifer flings herself at the screen, as Dick Van Dyke appears all over again.
Noooooo!
You--you gotta get us out of here.
(recoiling slightly)
Why would I do that?
Because we don't belong!
Oh sure you do ... "McIntire's Department store" ... "Their father dressed as Prince Charming." That was gorgeous Bud.
My name's David.
(wailing on the floor)
Oh GOD ...
(a little snippy)
You know--this is a pretty strange way of showing your appreciation.
Look--we appreciate it. We really do. We just--we want to go home now.
(hurt)
But you don't know how long I've been looking for someone like you. A long face slowly descends on him.
I'm very disappointed ... (deep breath)
In fact ... I'm starting to get a little upset. David moves toward the screen.
Don't get upset.
(snapping back)
Weil wouldn't you! You look for someone for years ... You pour your heart into it ... This is a privilege you know. (shakes his head)
I don't think I better talk about this right now.
Where are you going ...
I don't think we should discuss this until I'm a little bit more composed.
(turning his back)
Maybe in a day or so when I'm not so emotional ...

Dick Van Dyke shakes his head and walks out of the shot a the screen goes completely BLACK. It cuts out entirely as Jennifer and David just stare. David grabs the remote and starts rapidly pushing buttons. Nothing happens.
(dropping the gizmo)
Oh God.
What's going to happen?
I don't know ... It's not possible ... (looking at her)
Is it possible?
Bu-ud ... Mary Sue ... Your breakfast is getting cold.
It can't be possible. DIFFERENT ANGLE. Betty (their "mother") sticks her head into the living ro wearing her black and white apron. She has a great big Pepsodent smile.
Well, come on kids. You're not going off to school without a hot breakfast inside you ... They just stare at her.
Forward march. They exchange a strange little glance then slowly rise to their feet. Jennifer waits for David who forces a smile t starts toward the kitchen.
I just love you in that sweater Mary-Sue. It's so flattering.
(dazed)

Thanks. INT. KITCHEN. David and Jennifer walk two steps into the kitchen when t suddenly freeze--agape at the spectacle in front of them: THEIR POV. PARKER KITCHEN. Every breakfast food imaginable has been laid upon the ta There are hotcakes and sausages and biscuits and eggs. Pitchers of orange juice are dwarfed by the mountains of The table literally sags under the weight of the food. Ge Parker lowers his morning paper and smiles at his childre
(once again)

Morning kids. Better get a move on or you're going to be late for school. They nod, stunned, and wander forward into the room. Brig sunlight streams through the kitchen window as a gentle symphony of songbirds sings outside. David and Jennifer s straight ahead as their "mother" adds some waffles to the heap.
(under his breath)
I don't believe this.
Neither do I.
Well, c'mon. Dig in. David and Jennifer stare at her stunned as she puts two heaping plates at their places. Neither one moves.
(to Jennifer)
I put blueberries in them just the way you like.
Actually--I'm not real ... hungry.
(big smile)
Oh nonsense young lady. You're going to start your day with a nice big breakfast. She takes Jennifer by the shoulders and "guides" her into chair. Jennifer looks down at a huge plate of GRAY WAFFLE
(oppressively chipper)
Here. Why don't you have some waffle cakes. (beat)
And there's sausage and eggs and some good crisp bacon ... (beat)
... And a ham steak. Betty drenches the waffles in syrup and slathers on a hug slab of butter.

... And of course, a nice big bowl of oatmeal. Jennifer hesitates then glances over at her "mother" who looks at her expectantly. She glances at David who just l stunned. Jennifer pauses then reaches down and takes a forkful of the oozing mess ...

He stands facing the CAMERA in an actual Kinescope from 1 The backdrop is a painted pastoral landscape and the background singers are all white debutantes. He wears a letterman's sweater and button down shirt ...
"... Tooty fruity--oh rooty. Tooty Fruity ... Oh rooty." He CONTINUES his homogenized version of Little Richard's nasty hit, (all the nastiness gone). It becomes a slow an lilting melody ...

"... Tooty fruity--oh rooty ..." SERIES OF SHOTS. PLEASANTVILLE. The MUSIC CONTINUES as the CAMERA CUTS TO image after ima of this strange "Utopia." The effect is a weird, sanitizi version of MTV--as if Ronald Reagan had shot a music vide There are men tipping their hats and women walking their dogs; cheery gas station attendants and smiling policemen
(slowly ...)

"... A wap bop a loo bop--a wap barn boom." Pruned hedges. Twin beds. BIG houses. The CAMERA CRANES D in the middle of a beautiful tree lined street to find Da and Jennifer walking up the sidewalk, holding their stoma
I'm gonna hurl, David. I swear to God.
Just take deep breaths.
All that animal fat. I feel it in my pores or something. Jennifer clutches her stomach, but David's glance darts f side to side--totally absorbed.
I still don't see why we're doing this.
We're supposed to be in school.
We're supposed to be at home David! We're supposed to be in color! (wailing)
Oh God ... A man calls out from across the street.
Hello Bud.
Hello Mr. Simpson.
Hear your Dad got a new car.
Oh yeah. A Buick. It's swell.
You know him?
Owns the hardware store.
Okay, now you listen to me! I don't know what's going on but you'd better fix it! I had a date with Mark Davis and I even bought new UNDERWEAR!
We just gotta play along for a little while ... till that guy shows up again. Then I'll talk to him and ...
Play along?
Well, yeah. I'm ... Bud Parker and you're ... um--Mary Sue.
(ripping the barette from her hair)
No! I'm not gonna do it! If I don't dress like this for Mom I'm sure as hell not going to do it for you!
We don't have a choice Jen. We're stuck until he comes back.
Why can't we just EXPLAIN IT?

To who? Jen looks around this cheery little street, and the horro starts to dawn on her. At that moment, they hear a scream SIREN and a bright GRAY FIRE ENGINE comes racing up the block. WIDER. Jennifer and David step back on the curb as the firemen c flying out of the truck, grabbing the ladder on the back.

They work in perfect precision. Two firemen grab the base the ladder while a third takes the front. They go tearing across one of the lawns, in full "emergency response" anchoring the ladder into the ground and winging it up in tree.
C'mere, kitty ... He emerges a moment later with the cat who was stuck in t tree. Jennifer sinks to the curb as he carries the kitten them, petting it gently as he goes.
Oh God, we are. We're stuck in like "Nerdville". (shakes her head)
I always knew you'd pay a price for this. I knew you couldn't be hopelessly geekridden for this long without suffering some like, really tragic consequences. (voice wavering)

... But it's just not fair. I mean--I'm starting to get really--popular. Debbi Russell transferred to another school and my skin's been great since March and Mark Davis is starting to come around and ...

Hello Mary Sue. Jennifer turns to see a strapping blonde seventeen year o driving by in his convertible. He is extremely handsome w Jack Armstrong features and a Letterman's sweater. Despit her crisis, Jennifer's jaw drops open as he slows to a cr Biff Martin flashes a huge Pepsodent smile. The guy is a "dreamboat".
What's all the commotion? Where's the cat?
Um ... It's ... Biff turns to see the fireman climb into the truck, with kitty in his arms.
Ah, right ... (smiling at her again)
Well--guess I'll see ya later Mary Sue. He takes off down the street with the sun glinting on his really keen convertible. Jennifer gapes as he disappears around the corner.
Who's that?
Biff Martin. Captain of the basketball team.
(still gaping)
Does he--you know--like "me"?
As a matter of fact he does.
(flicking her hair)
Hunh.

Streams of impeccably kept youngsters file through the do doors. All cheery and very pleasant looking. It looks lik Leni Riefenstahl movie. ANGLE. FROM ACROSS THE STREET. David stands beside Jennifer looking at the entrance to t school. Three girls huddle together by the front steps.
Those are my friends.
Peggy Jane, Lisa Anne and Betty Jean.
(staring at them)
Can we do any better?
I don't think so.
(seeing her)
Mary Sue. You're gonna be late for Geography.
Okay ... She flicks her hair back--cops a first day of school attitude, and heads across the street like she owns the place.

It looks like a propaganda film from the Eisenhower Administration. The boys all wear crew cuts and short sle button down shirts. The girls all have lacy dresses butto to the neck. Everyone stares straight ahead at the blackboard. ANGLE. FRONT OF THE ROOM. TEACHER. Miss Peters stands in front of the class with a pointer i her hand. She indicates a diagram that spans the length o the blackboard.

Last week Class, we discussed the geography of Main Street. This week, we're going to be talking about Elm Street. Can anyone tell me one of the differences between Elm Street and Main Street? (pointing)
Tommy.
It's not as long? Jennifer looks stunned as several students nod.

That's right, Tommy. It's not as long. Also, it only has houses. So the geography of Main Street is different than the geography of Elm Street. ANGLE. JENNIFER. She glances around at several students who seem to be nod in agreement. All at once, she thrusts her hand into the
Mary Sue.
What's outside of Pleasantville? The teacher looks at her with a puzzled frozen smile on h face. She looks vaguely troubled.
What? (beat)
I don't understand ...

Outside of Pleasantville ... What's at the end of Main Street? The class lets out a knowing groan--as if to say "Oh. We it now. Boy what a stupid question." Miss Peters gives a but condescending look.

Oh, Mary Sue. You should know the answer to that. The end of Main Street is just the beginning again. Miss Peters gives a big grin as a series of heads nod up down. Jennifer stares straight ahead, dumbfounded ...

There are fifteen to twenty boys scattered around the Gym Each is dressed identically in white shorts and black soc with a "PLEASANTVILLE" jersey. SHOT. DAVID. He stands at the free throw line with a basketball in his hand. (Not exactly an athletic image.) David lets go of a jump shot that swishes effortlessly through the net. He l a little surprised.

Wow. He stares at the backboard slightly intrigued. David retrieves the ball and fires again, this time chucking it up blind. The ball sails through the hoop again, HITTING NOTHING BUT NET. FULL SHOT. OTHER SIDE OF THE GYM. Ten to twelve of his teammates fire simultaneously at the hoop. ALL OF THE SHOTS SAIL THROUGH THE HOOP, NONE EVEN NICKING THE RIM. The boys retrieve their shots as the coa claps his hands.

That's it men. Keep it up. Big game tomorrow. ANGLE. DAVID. He gets the ball and turns his back on the basket complet David flings the ball wildly over his shoulder. It bounce off all the walls of the gym, then glides through the net smoothly as the others. He stares in amazement.
Bud ... WIDER. Biff Martin (the boy in the convertible) approaches from other side of the Gym. He is a classic All American Hero- somewhere between 4-H club member and a future astronaut.
(a little nervous)
Hi ya Bud.
Hi ya Biff. He fidgets nervously for a moment looking down.
Can I ask you a question?
Sure.
Well ... If I was to ask your sister ... What I mean is, if I was to go up to Mary Sue ...
Oh God! Are we in that episode?
What?
I don't believe it.
What's the matter?
You want to ask her out tonight, right? And then you want to give her your school pin ...
Yeah ... How'd you know?
(shaking his head)
Lucky guess. (beat)
Look, Biff ... I don't think it's a real good time for that right now ... Biff's expression falls. He stands crushed in front of Da
What I mean is ... Mary Sue's been a little "different" lately ...
(stunned)
She won't go out with me?
I didn't say that. It's just that right now ...

I don't know what I'd do if she wouldn't go out with me ... All at once, Biff takes the basketball he's been holding hurls it toward the hoop. The ball does a couple of revolutions of the rim, and then amazingly pops out. WIDE ANGLE. GYM. Play comes to a halt. ALL THE PLAYERS TURN AND STARE, DUMBSTRUCK AT THE SIGHT OF A MISSED SHOT. SHOT. DAVID. He retrieves the ball quickly then hurries back to Biff. David pulls him aside as play slowly resumes on the other side of the gym.
(under his breath)
Look, I'm sure we'll work something out. I'll talk to her or something. Biff looks at him, troubled.
Honest. It'll be fine. Biff nods, a little confused, as David pats him on the ba
David stands off to the side with his sister, while class pours out around them.
No way.
One date, Jen--that's all I'm asking. If you don't go out with this guy we could throw their whole universe out of whack.
It's too weird David. This place is giving me the creeps. Did you know all the books are blank?
What?
I looked in the library. They got covers with nothing inside them.
What were you doing in a library?
I got lost. (beat)
Oh here ... look at this! She reaches into her purse and pulls out a book of matche Jennifer tries to light a Kleenex on fire.
Just watch. You know why those guys just get cats out of trees? 'Cause nothing burns around here, that's why! They don't need any firemen ... Sure enough the tissue has become flame retardant.
Jen, listen ...
(trembling)
I like--really need a cigarette, too.
(putting his arm around her)
I'll get us out of here. I really will. But if we don't play along we could alter their whole existence. We may never get home. She looks over at him, slowly.

You really think anybody's gonna, like, notice if I don't have a chocolate malt with this guy. At that moment, three of Mary Sue's "friends" come titter around the comer. They skitter up to her like a group of wind-up toys.
(high-pitched--rapid fire)
You won't believe what we just heard.
Biff Martin's going to ask you out.
And that's not all ...
No, that's not all ...

He's going to give you his pin! They explode in a torrent of TITTERS all over again. Jenn looks over at David. EXT. PARKER HOUSE. DUSK. A lone streetlamp glows in the foreground. Jennifer's voi plays OS.

You sure I'm supposed to wear this? INT. MARY SUE'S ROOM. Jennifer emerges from the closet in a mohair sweater and poodle skirt. Under the sweater she wears a 1950's "bulle bra" that turn her breasts into lethal weapons.
(looking in the mirror)
I could like kill a guy with these things.
It's in your closet.
(examining her profile)
I've worn some kinky stuff before ...
He won't notice anyway.
What do you mean?
They don't notice that kind of thing.
So what's the point?
Jen please ...
He-llo? I've got like three pounds of underwire here ...
Just go with the program--hunh? I'm late for work.

The flashing neon ice cream cone looks good enough to dri Underneath it, the swirling script spells "SODA SHOP". Jo Mathis drifts out into the evening air ... CLOSER. David comes sprinting up to the screen door and pauses to his breath. He adjusts a little soda jerk's hat, then plu inside. INT. SODA SHOP. Mr. Johnson, the owner and proprietor is wiping down the counter. He is a "pleasant" looking man, in his early for wearing a white apron and black glasses. The strains of "MISTY" get louder as Bud lets the screen door slam behin him.
(looking up)
Bud?
Sorry ... I had to help my folks and then I couldn't find my hat ...
Oh. He stops wiping for a moment, holding the towel in his ha
I didn't know what to do. He stares at the rag a little troubled.
What's wrong?
Well--I always wipe down the counter and then you set out the napkins and glasses and then I make the french fries ...
(confused)
Yeah ...
But you didn't come so I kept on wiping. He looks down at the towel clearly disturbed. David pause for a moment then starts toward him.
I'm sorry. He crosses to Mr. Johnson who has polished one section of counter right down to the wood. David takes the towel out his hand and folds it neatly in front of him.
(gently)
You know, if this ever happens again, you can make the fries even if I haven't put out the napkins yet.
I'm so glad you're here.

I understand. EXT. PARKER HOUSE. NIGHT. Biff's convertible rolls up to the curb with Pat Boone playing on the radio. He runs a comb through his short bl hair before grabbing the bouquet of flowers next to him a heading up the walk. Biff rings the doorbell and, a momen later, Jennifer's silhouette appears in the doorway ...

Oh. Mary Sue ... EXT. SODA SHOP. NIGHT. The place is really hopping now. All the spots in the par lot are filled with vintage "jalopies" and several patron are streaming through the door. The SAME JOHNNY MATHIS SO is still PLAYING on the juke box, and the neon ice cream sign blinks against the sky. INT. SODA SHOP. David is trapped behind the counter, furiously working to keep up with the load. Several clean cut teenagers pepper with orders while he yanks at the pumps and spiggots. It' clear he isn't used to this.
(frazzled)
Peppermint shake, chocolate soda, two orders of fries and a split?

Peppermint soda, two chocolate shakes, order of fries, and we'll split it. David nods quickly, wiping some sweat from his brow. He scoops some ice cream into the metal blender as Mr. Johns comes up beside him.
There aren't any cheeseburgers.
(turning)
What?
Well, usually I put out the burger and then you finish with the lettuce ...
Listen to me! Mr. Johnson recoils slightly.
Do you have the lettuce?
... Yeah.
Have you cooked the burgers?
(quieter)
Yes.
Well you can just put on the lettuce, finish the burger and pretend it was me doing it all along. Mr. Johnson stares at him.

Really. It's fine. DIFFERENT ANGLE. SODA SHOP ENTRANCE. The screen door swings open and is held there by the end Letterman's sweater. A moment later, Jennifer sashays through, parading her new Jane Russell profile. Her "girlfriends" TITTER from the comer as Biff rushes up to table, and pulls out a chair. She sashays into it, brushi against him as she goes. ANGLE. DAVID. He stares motionless at the spectacle--concerned and apprehensive. David holds a hot fudge sundae under the so spiggot and jerks back on the lever blowing ice cream all over his chest. FULL SHOT. TABLE. Biff stares across the table at Jennifer with the wholeso devotion of a labrador retriever. He looks like a cross between Troy Donahue and a mannequin.
(haltingly)
I sure am glad you said you'd come out with me tonight Mary Sue.
(full blown "Mary Sue")
Well "gee whizz" Biff. I sure am glad you asked me. He guffaws for a moment or two before speaking again.
I don't know if I ever said this to you before, but, well ... I think you're just about the keenest girl in the whole school ...
Really Biff? The keenest?
Oh yeah.
(all sarcasm)
Gosh. I hardly know what to say.

What can I get you two? WIDER. He stands at their table holding a little white pad of pa and a pencil. Jennifer looks up at her brother and almost bursts out laughing. He wears his soda jerk hat at a jaun angle with large white apron tied around his neck.
Oh, I dunno Bud. Guess I'll have my usual cheeseburger and a cherry coke. More goony laughs. David turns to Jennifer who puts on th same dopey countenance.
Oh, I dunno Bud. Guess I'll just have a salad and an Evian Water. He shoots her a dirty look. Jennifer just smiles at him.

Cheeseburger it is. ANGLE. FOLLOWING DAVID. He glowers at her all the way back to the counter. David posts the order in the little carousel clip board, keepin eye on the table the entire time ... RESUME. TABLE. Biff gazes across the table at Jennifer with an adoring l on his face. His hands are properly folded in front of hi She's still trying to do her best "Mary Sue."

See the whole time we were in civics together, I really wanted to sit next to you--but you were always sitting between Peggy Jane and Lisa Anne. There is some TITTERING behind her. Jennifer doesn't resp
... And you always seemed so smart and everything. Like that report you did on "Our Town Hall." Gosh. I didn't know what I'd talk to you about.
Well, sometimes talking's over-rated. Don't you think?
Hunh? (goony laugh)

Oh, right ... He still doesn't understand. Biff GUFFAWS for a moment or then glances down at the table top. There is a momentary break in the Music as Johnny Mathis' "MISTY" starts up al over again. It's enough to make you shoot yourself.
So I know I haven't been steady with anybody, but I just don't want to rush it. You don't want to make a mistake with something that important.
Oh, gosh no.
I mean, there's kids that are even holding hands already but I figure there's plenty of time for that kind of thing later on. Don't you?
Oh you bet. (beat)

Will you excuse me for a sec? Jennifer gets up in a daze and heads toward the bathroom. ANGLE. DAVID. He freezes behind the counter and watches as his sister practically stumbles through the bathroom door. INT. BATHROOM. Of course there aren't any toilets. Jennifer gropes her w to the sink and leans against the counter.
Jesus Chirist ... She turns and sits against the sink for a moment with a dumbstruck look on her face. Jennifer shakes her head for moment or two, when the door to the bathroom bursts open.
(overlapping)
"Did he give it to you ... Did he give it to you ... I bet he gave it to her ... Did he give it to you?"
(straight ahead)
I don't think he knows how. They TITTER away, even though they don't get it either. I sounds like an aviary.
I bet he's gonna take her to Lover's Lane.
I bet he is. I bet he is.
I bet he's even gonna hold her hand! They TITTER some more as Jennifer shakes her head. INT. SODA SHOP. David is standing beside their table as she retums from t bathroom.
(chipper)
Couple of cheeseburgers and two cherry cokes. (pointedly)
If you need anything, I'll be right over there.
(Mary Sue)

Gee whiz "Bud", what could we possibly need when we have each other? She flashes him a "sweet" smile then reaches out and TOUC BIFF'S HAND. Both boys jump slightly as Jennifer gives he brother a venomous grin then suddenly waves "bye bye." Da just stares at her panicked as he moves haltingly back to Soda fountain.
(befuddled)
Anyhow ... I really wanted to come over and sit next to you in civics but ...
You want to get out of here?
What?
You wanna get out of here? You wanna leave?
(confused)
But where would we go?
(shrugging)
... Lover's Lane.
(swallow)
Lover's Lane! There is an audible GASP from the booth behind them. Jenn ignores it.
Yeah. Lover's Lane. You up for it? CLOSE UP. BIFF. He just stares at her with his mouth open ... WIDER. Jennifer reaches forward grabbing his hand.

C'mon. Let's go. FULL SHOT. SODA FOUNTAIN. David is in the middle of making a hot fudge sundae when sees Jennifer leading Biff by the hand into the parking l Everyone at the counter is enjoying their dessert, when D lets out a blood curdling scream.

He vaults over the counter making a bee-line for the door Everyone turns and stares as he races toward the entrance EXT. SODA SHOP. Biff's car is just pulling onto the street when David spr into the parking lot. He takes off after the car, sprinti down the street.
The tail lights recede in the distance as David slows to jog and then finally a walk. He pauses, winded, in the street, then looks up toward Heaven with a pissed off loo his face.
(to God)
Thanks a lot.

It is a beautiful tree-lined pond with a lush willow tree the foreground. The moonlight glistens silver across the water. Several cars are parked in a row with their occupa HOLDING HANDS. Biff's convertible is parked at the end. SHOT. BIFF'S CAR. He sits stiffly at the wheel staring straight ahead. Jenn is draped languidly across the seat beside him, making th most of her mohair sweater. She stares at Biff in a not-s Pleasantville-kind-of-way. He glances over at her and swallows.
Sure is pretty.
(staring at him)
Oh yeah ... Gorgeous.
To be honest Mary Sue. I didn't think you'd want to come here until we'd been pinned for a little while.
Oh, Biff. You can "pin" me any time you want to. She leans back a liftle more, draping her arm across the of the seat. Her tits point toward the sky.
(breathy)
Or maybe I should just "pin" you. He looks over at her a little confused, then breaks into goony laugh.
Oh, that's silly Mary Sue. How could you possibly pin me? CLOSE UP. BIFF. He is still guffawing when he looks over at Jennifer and suddenly freezes. Biff's eyes widen ...
David comes sprinting up to the porch, then doubles over catching his breath. He clings onto the porch swing when door opens behind him.
Bud? WIDER. His "mother" and "father" come out onto the porch. David catches his breath then forces a smile.
Son, what's wrong?
Have you seen Mary Sue?
Why no. She's still on her date with Biff ... is something the matter?
(still panting a little)
No, I ... I was just ... worried about her. His mother and father exchange a "knowing" look. George r a hand on his shoulder.
(oppressively paternal)
Bud, your sister's a little older now and she's naturally going to start going out with boys. (beat)
... In fact pretty soon--she's even going to get married and make someone a good little home-maker like your mother here. (smiles at Betty/ inside joke)
That's IF she can learn to bake.
Oh, George ...
But your sister is a fine young woman and she would never do anything for us to be concerned about.

The low gutteral MOANS of two coupling animals drifts out over the evening air. It is raw and primitive and despera The CAMERA begins to TRACK behind all the other cars--the occupants primly holding hands in a tender sillouhette. I finally COMES TO REST on a convertible at the end, with a girl's leg sticking out the window. CLOSER. A Letterman's sweater hangs over the door. The windshield completely fogged. Jennifer's sweater is draped over the backseat. The car is rocking. INT. CAR. They are clenched in a mad embrace: all arms and hair. Bi pulls back for a moment, GASPING for air. His face is cov with lipstick and there is a crazy look in his eye. He's stuck somewhere between passion and fear as he clings desperately to the steering wheel.
(some terror)
I think I better go home now Mary Sue ... She holds onto his shirt as her knee rubs the dashboard.
(breathless)
... Why?
(more terror)
I think ... I might be ill ... He glances down at his lap a little confused.
(a whisper)
I think something's happening to me. He looks at his crotch then back at Jennifer. She reaches and grabs a handful of his hair.
It's s'posed to happen, Biff.
It is?
Trust me ... He looks at her completely confused as she pulls back dow and OUT OF FRAME ...
A single light is burning in the kitchen window.
Do you want some more cookies? INT. KITCHEN. David is at the kitchen table with a nauseated look on hi face. There are three empty bottles of milk and cookie cr all over the table.
(sick)
Oh no ... I'm fine.
How 'bout some Marshmallow Rice Squares?
I'm fine. There is a knock behind them at the door. David springs u
Now who could that be. FOLLOWING DAVID. He crosses into the foyer ahead of his "parents." David swings open the door revealing Mr. Johnson, standing on t porch.
Oh hi!
Hi there. You took off so quick. I wasn't sure if you were okay.
Oh, yeah. Sorry. I'm fine. I just ... Had to get home early. Mr. Johnson leans in closer and speaks in a CONFIDENTIAL of voice.
Bud ...
Yeah ...
(sotto)
You know how when we close up, I close the register, then you lower the shades, then I turn out the lights, then we both lock the doors.
Yeah ...
(proud)

Well you weren't around this time so I did the whole thing myself. CLOSER. Mr. Johnson has a strange look of "manly pride" on his fa His shoulders square back. His chest puffs out a little. There is a sudden sparkle in his eye.
(more confidential)
Not only that, I didn't even do it in the same order. First I lowered the shades, then I closed the register. He looks at David with pride then suddenly shifts his gla behind him.
Oh, hello Betty.
Hello Bill. Neither one says anything but neither one has to. David l on in horror as his mother locks eyes with Mr. Johnson an his new found virility.
(quickly)

Well, look, thanks for coming by. I ... really appreciate it. He turns and starts hustling him down the walk just as Bi convertible pulls up at the curb. INT. CAR. CLOSE UP. JENNIFER. She looks sweetly over at the driver's side of the car (O OF FRAME).

Well gee thanks Biff. I had a really wonderful time. ANGLE. BIFF. OTHER SIDE OF CAR. He sits behind the wheel with a totally dazed look on his face. Biff stares stunned at Jennifer, like he just got h with a couple of thousand volts.

... Me too. She leans over and kisses him on the cheek ... Then she b his ear lobe, gently, and flashes him a big smile. Biff smiles back. EXT. CAR. She climbs out and shuts the door. Jennifer nods to Mr. Johnson as she heads up the walk.
(sweetly)
Hello Mr. Johnson.
Oh, hello Mary Sue. She is wearing a big smile by the time she reaches the po David grabs her arm.
(urgent whisper)
What did you do to him?
(innocently)
Nothing. She starts up the staircase. David follows her and the CA follows them both.
What do you mean "nothing?" That's not nothing. That's ... She reaches the top of the stairs and turns to him.
Relax "Bud." We had a really nice time. (mock YAWN)
... Now I'm really tired and we gotta get up early for school in the morning so ... She flashes her brother an evil grin.

'Night. She shuts the door softly in his face. David stairs at th gray wood in front of him. EXT. ELM STREET. NIGHT. Biff pulls up at an intersection with the same dazed look his eye. The car rumbles at the stoplight for a moment or two, before he glances over to his right. CLOSE UP. BIFF. The stunned look turns to one of sheer amazement: BIFF'S POV. ROSE. There, against a gray picket fence, on a black and white street in a black and white neighborhood, A SINGLE RED RO IS BLOOMING.

It would be a stunning vista if it wasn't in black and wh The church steeple gleams in the sunlight. The perfect li houses look like a row of pretty toys ... INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. DAY. David sits parked in front of the TV furtively turning through the channels. He flips the dial frantically. No s of Dick Van Dyke.
Bud. It's 7:30 in the morning. Are you watching television? He gives her a sheepish grin and sighs ...

It is the same configuration as earlier. Everyone wears t Pleasantville "Lions" jerseys, white sneakers and black socks. David enters the Gym a little groggy. He hasn't ha much sleep. CLOSER. He looks up and stops. David cocks his head to the side, staring across the gym. HIS POV. BIFF AND OTHER BOYS. They are huddled at the far end, each holding a basketbal under his arm. Biff is in the center of the group, animat describing something that is holding their RAPT ATTENTION WIDER ANGLE. INCLUDING DAVID.
(quietly)
Oh no ... Biff continues his story while they stare at him with the mouths open. The Coach blows his whistle.

Come on men. Let's go. Big game next week. The huddle breaks up as the basketball players all wander toward the hoop. Ten shots go up at once but NOT ONE COME EVEN CLOSE. Several clang off the rim, a couple hit the e of the backboard. One slams into the side of the gym. Everyone stares in disbelief.
Oh my God ...
David stands face to face with his sister in mid conversation.
You can't do this, Jennifer. I WARNED you.
So what's the big deal. Oh. Okay. They're like not good at basketball anymore. Like--omigod, what a tragedy.
You don't understand. You're messing with their UNIVERSE.
Well maybe it needs to be messed with. Did that ever like--occur to you? (beat)
You know, they don't want to be like this, it's just that nobody ever helped them before.
(walking past)
"MS". How you doin'?
Kewl "PJ". How you doin'?
(relishing her new word)
"Kewl." Jennifer smiles at her friend as she goes by.
You have no right to do this.
Well if I don't who will?
They're happy like this.
David, nobody's happy in a Poodle skirt and a sweater set. (pause ...)
You like all this don't you? David recoils slightly.
I mean, you don't think it's just like dorky or funny or something ... you really like it. (shudders)
Oh God! I am just so personally horrified right now ...
I just don't think we have the right to ...
David, let me tell you something. These people don't want to be geeks. They want to be "attractive." They've got a lot of potential, they just don't know any better.
They don't have that kind of potential.

Um--hello? You want to like take a look? Jennifer motions behind her to a boy and girt who are loc in an intimate conversation. The girl wears bobby socks a the boy wears a letterman's sweater, but the conversation sexually charged. They speak to one another in a close whisper--their faces inches apart. All at once the girt g shy and glances away. She blows a big bubble with her gum but the BUBBLE IS BRIGHT PINK IN AN OTHERWISE GRAY FRAME.
Wow. What kind of gum is that? CLOSE. DAVID AND JENNIFER. He looks over in shock as she sucks the BRIGHTLY COLORED BUBBLE GUM back into her mouth. Jennifer flicks her hair.

I gotta go. I'm meeting Biff at the flagpole. EXT. LOVER'S LANE. NIGHT. It is the exact same shot as before: The CAMERA STARTS IT LONG SLOW TRACK behind the vehicles, except this time ALL THEM ARE ROCKING. Various limbs and articles of clothing out the open windows. MOANS of pleasure waft out over Lov Lane as the pond glistens in the distance ...

It is a typical '50s family practice right out of Norman Rockwell. There is a jar of tongue depressors on the coun and a jar of lollipops beside them. Lisa Anne (Mary Sue's best friend) is being examined by Dr. Henderson. Her moth sits at her side.
Let me see it again. Lisa Anne opens her mouth and sticks out a BRIGHT RED TON Everything else in the frame is Black and White, but her tongue literally gleams with color.
(examining it)
Well ... I don't think it's anything to worry about ... It'll probably just clear up by itself. (to Lisa Anne)
Cut down on greasy foods and chocolate. No french fries, that kind of thing. (aside/ to the Mother)
It's just a "teenage" thing. EXT. LOVER'S LANE. NIGHT. It is really rocking now. More cars are lined up along th edge of the lake as the REAL (AND NASTY) VERSION OF TOOTY
"... Got a gal--her name is Sue. She knows just what to do ..."

head_text.subj: TOOTY FRUITY CONTINUES AS DAVID FLIPS FRANTICALLY THROUGH
CHANNELS LOOKING FOR DICK VAN DYKE. THERE IS ONLY A PEPSO

text: The Pleasantville Lions lose a game late in the second ha The scoreboard reads 84 to 16 ...
David examines the back of the TV set ...

A large group of customers is huddled in a circle, starin an item on the display floor, like it is the monolith in "2001". They seem both confused and absolutely mesmerized the CAMERA PUSHES IN TO REVEAL: a double bed ...
David sits on the floor with a weird look of resignation Brillcream commercial plays in front of him ...

"... A wop bop a loo bop--a wop bam boom!" SODA SHOP. NIGHT. ON DAVID. He heads toward work with his apron and his paper hat, bu he's clearly disconcerted. David stops and stares at A BR RED HOT ROD parked at the front door of the restaurant. H shakes his head. SODA SHOP. The place has been transformed. What was cheery and benig couple of days before, has gotten a little bit dangerous. letterman sweaters have been replaced by leather jackets. Pat Boone and Johnny Mathis have given way to real Rock a Roll. There is a James Dean/Marlon Brando edge in the air Somebody has played the flip side. ANGLE. DAVID. He enters the soda shop adjusting his paper hat. A young couple makes out passionately in the doorway--all tongues hands. When they break David sees that the girl's cheeks FLUSHED WITH RED. He stares at her for a beat as they ret to normal. David shakes his head. FOLLOWING HIM. He crosses to the counter and grabs his pencil and little of paper. Various things have already GONE TO COLOR AROUN THE ROOM: The JUKE BOX ... The COKE SIGN .. THE NAUGAHIDE STOOLS ... David crosses to one of the booths where his sister's arm is draped over Biff's shoulder.
What'll it be?
(still chipper as ever)
Gee whizz, Bud. Guess I'll just have the usual. Cheeseburger and a cherry coke. Bud has already written it down. He glances over at his sister.
Me too. Sounds swell.
(pointed)
Really? It seems so fattening. Before she can answer he smiles to himself and crosses be the counter. Bud posts the order and turns to Mr. Johnson
Two cheeseburgers, two cherry cokes.
(staring straight ahead)
There aren't any cheeseburgers.
(exasperated)
Look. I thought we talked about this, I thought we said ...
Oh--what's the point, Bud? CLOSER. Mr. Johnson. looks up at him with a weird kind of emptine in his eyes. David grabs his arm.

C'mere. He pulls him along the counter toward a little office storeroom in the back. He yanks him inside and shuts the door. INT. STOREROOM. It is just as cheery as the rest of the place. There is a small table with a telephone on it. A Texaco calendar sho happy family motoring in their Rambler.
What did you say? Mr. Johnson glances down with a little shame and confusio
Well ... I'm not sure I see the point anymore.
What are you talking about! You make hamburgers! That is the point!
No I know ... I know I do ... (he pauses, then looks up)
But it's always the same, you know? Grill the bun, flip the meat, melt the cheese ... It never changes. It never gets any better or worse ...
Just listen to me ...
(not hearing him)
... Like the other night, when I closed up by myself. That was different ...
Forget about that!
Oh ... Okay. (beat/ lower)
... But I really liked it. Bud takes a deep breath. He stares at Mr. Johnson, then t to speak softly.
Look, you can't always like what you do. Sometimes you just do it because it's your job. And even if you don't like it, you just gotta do it anyway.
Why?
(exasperated)
So they can have their hamburgers! This sounds stupid even to David. He shakes his head.
(like a secret)
You know what I really like?
(warily)
... What's that?
Christmastime. David rolls his eyes. Mr. Johnson leans closer, speaking furtively.
See every year on Dec 3, I get to paint the Christmas decorations in the window. And every year, I get to paint a different thing ... (beat)
One year it's the North Pole. The next I do Santa's workshop. Here I'll show you. He pulls a photo album from the back of the desk and open it for David.
(impressed)
Wow ... That's pretty good ...
Thanks. (continuing)

But this morning I was thinking about it and I realized that I looked forward to it all year. And then I thought "Gee. That seems awfully silly. That seems like an awfully long time to be waiting for just one moment, don't you think?" David looks at him speechless.
Well don't you?
I think you should try not to think about this anymore.
Really?
Yeah.
Oh. Okay. I'll try that then.

The Barber Pole spins in three shades of gray. Several me are gathered around the two chairs in the front of Gus' s Besides being the barbershop, it is the bastion of all ma life in Pleasantville. Bud and Mary Sue's "father" (Georg sits in one of the chairs. "Big Bob" McGee, owner of the drugstore, supermarket and Chevy dealership sits in the other. He has a crew cut that's getting shorter.
Have they ever lost before?
Basketball? No they sure haven't.
Just feels "wrong", that's all. There are several murmurs.
Maybe that's where they get that saying, "can't win 'em all."
Yeah. That's a good point, Ralph. They do have that saying.
But they do win 'em all, Gus. They've always won 'em all.
Well, yeah. That's true too. More murmurs, Everyone looks straight ahead trying to fig

The women's bridge club has assembled in the Parker kitch like it does every Wednesday afternoon. Four women are se around the kitchen table with a nice bowl of bridge mix between them. Betty is sifting next to Marge Jenkins, the woman who accompanied her daughter to the doctor's office
(dealing the cards)
... He said it would clear up on its own if she just stayed away from fried foods and sweets ...
Well that makes sense.
Except it's spread to her lips now too. Oh, I don't know.
(a THIRD WOMAN)
And you say it's just "red?"
Well--like red, only ... "redder."

Hunh. I know what you mean. That's like the front of Bill Johnson's shop. I was going by it the other day and it looked green only "greener." SHOT. BETTY. She looks up quickly--then grabs some bridge mix.
(lowering her voice)

Have you seen him lately? The man doesn't look like himself. I was getting my sewing machine fixed across the street and he was sitting in the window of his shop just staring. Wasn't looking at anything in particular--just staring off into space.

That is strange. Betty reaches out and grabs her cards. She fans them out front of her, when her eyes go wide. HER POV. BRIDGE HAND. They are ALL HEARTS and all BRIGHT RED. It looks like a fistfful of valentines. CLOSE UP. BETTY. She puts the cards down quickly and takes a sudden breath Betty keeps them like that for a moment or two, before lifting them up and taking another look.
Betty, it's your bid. She swallows trying to keep her composure.
Uh ... Seven hearts. They murmur at the strength of the hand.

The SOUND of the television plays OS while a warm light b in the window. INT. KITCHEN. Jennifer and Betty stand at the sink finishing the dishes Betty washes while Jennifer dries and it's clear who's mo used to this. Jennifer examines a chipped nail as she pla a dish in the drying rack.
Mary Sue?
Yeah? Betty hesitates. Rinses out a pot.
Can I ask you a question?
Sure. She pauses for a long moment.
What goes on up at Lover's Lane?
(turning toward her)
What do you mean?
Well, you hear all these things lately. You know--kids spending so much time up there ... (she looks over)
Is it holding hands? That kind of thing?
Yeah ... (beat)
That--and ... She stops herself.
What?
It doesn't matter.
No. I want to know.
(glances toward the living room/ lowers her voice)
... Sex.
Ah. Betty nods from the import of the tone but not the meanin beat goes by ...
What's sex? Jennifer looks over at her stunned, but Betty just looks her with a blank, curious expression. Jennifer hesitates.
You sure you want to know this?
Yes.
Okay. She crosses to the kitchen door and closes it. The sounds the TV in the living room disappear. Jennifer crosses bac the kitchen counter and turns to her.
You see Mom ... (softer and with understanding)
When two people like each other very much ... Betty looks at her and nods ...

The TV keeps flickering in the window. INT. KITCHEN. LATER ... The CAMERA PANS across the kitchen table where there is a full quart of milk and some uneaten co6kies. It finally c to rest on Jennifer who is staring across the kitchen tab with a concerned look on her face.
You okay? REVERSE ANGLE. BETTY. She nods--shaken but "fine." Betty stares long and hard a the plate of chocolate chip cookies. She's far away.
Yes ... (softly)
It's just that ...
(gently)
What?
Well ... (looking up)
... Your father would never do anything like that. SHOT. JENNIFER. She bites her lip weighing her next sentence ...
(leaning forward)
Oh. Hmm ... (whisper/ woman to woman)
Well, Mom ... there's ways to "enjoy" yourself without Dad. ANGLE. BETTY. She looks across the table, perplexed.

George crosses from the dresser to the TWO TWIN BEDS in t middle of the room. He wears long sleeve pajamas that are buttoned up to the neck. George puts his glass of warm mi on the nightstand and climbs in his own single bed. It is barely wide enough for his body and takes some maneuverin
Sweetie? You coming to bed? There is no answer.
Betty? INT. BATHROOM. She stands in her bathrobe staring down at the tub. Her dressing gown is buttoned to the neck as well.
(calling out)

Yeah ... I'm just going to take a bath first. CLOSER. BETTY. She swallows once as she stares down at the tub--then rea for the spigot and turns on the water. Betty's heart beat little faster as she HEARS the WATER THUNDERING DOWN. CLOSER STILL ... Betty reaches up and unties the little silk ribbon at the of her robe. She slips it off, and lets it drop to the fl standing naked in the middle of the bathroom. Betty glanc toward the mirror and then quickly glances away. She take deep breath and steps into the tub. EVEN TIGHTER. ON HER FACE ... Betty slides down into the warm water, breathing in the steam, and closing her eyes for a moment. She lingers lik that for a second or two, before settling a little lower the tub. Betty opens her eyes, but they only half open. T is the slight trace of a smile. EXTREME CLOSE UP BETTY'S FACE. Her eyes close again as she bites her lower lip gently. T water continues to THUNDER DOWN as she arches her back. Betty's breathing seems to quicken as she opens her eyes over again: HER POV. BATHROOM ...

head_text.subj: ALL AT ONCE, EVERYTHING AROUND STARTS TO TURN FROM BLACK
WHITE TO COLOR. A BIRD OUT THE WINDOW BECOMES A RED BREAS
ROBIN. THE TILE ON THE TUB TURNS OUT TO BE PURPLE. GREEN
TOWEL ... PINK ROBE ... BRIGHT YELLOW DAISIES ON THE PLAS

text: She stares in amazment. Beads of sweat form on Betty's forehead as the world goes to TECHNICOLOR. The THUNDERING WATER POUNDS IN THE BACKGROUND, but beneath can be heard beginnings of a faint, low, MOAN. Her eyes dart around th room. Her breathing quickens: Faster ... Harder ... More intense ... THEN SUDDENLY ... EXT. ELM STREET. NIGHT. The HUGE ELM TREE across the street suddenly BURSTS INTO FLAMES. Fire shoots straight up into the sky as billowing clouds of black smoke fill the air. BRIGHT ORANGE FLAMES LIGHT UP THE NIGHT. INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. David is staring at the television set when he notices a weird orange glow. He glances behind him, out the living window ...

Oh my God! EXT. ELM STREET. NIGHT. David comes racing out of the front door and down the wal small CROWD has gathered in front of the fire. (They don' seem frightened--just sort of amazed.) The street is stil BLACK AND WHITE but it is now bathed in a weird ORANGE LI The flames leap higher and higher ...

Jesus Christ ... FOLLOWING DAVID. He takes off down the block, as fast as he can run. The c continues to stare as David turns the corner at Main Street ... EXT. FIRE STATION. He races in the front of the building SCREAMING at the to his lungs.

There is no sign of life on the ground floor. David races the stairs toward the bunk room on the second story. INT. BUNKROOM. All the firemen are sitting around playing Gin Rummy when David rushes in the front door. They can hear his voice f down the hall.
(entering)
They still don't move. All the firemen just look at him f their bunks with a perplexed expression.
(beat)

All at once they spring to their feet grabbing their helm and their yellow slickers. They race to the landing just outside the bunkroom and leap onto the pole ... EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. The FIRE HAS SPREAD TO AN ADJOINING TREE as the FIRE ENGI comes SCREAMING toward the house from the top of the bloc David sits in the front of the truck next to the Fire Chi who drives the vehicle at break neck speed.
Right here! The Fire ENGINE screeches to a halt. The Fire Chief looks around ...

Where is it? David shoots him a look then glances at the inferno. He shakes his head and leaps from the truck. FOLLOWING DAVID. He races around to the back where the other firemen are standing just as confused. David grabs one of the hoses a begins to pull it from the truck.
Here! Grab this nozzle.
But where's the ...
Just grab it! He strips out about fifteen feet of hose, then grabs the fireman and pulls him toward the curb. David parts the cr and positions the man right in front of the flames.
(shouting)
Okay! Now point this right at the flames--like this. The Fireman nods and does as he is told. David opens the valve sending out a huge FLUME OF WATER.
Whoa! (beat)

So that's what these do. A huge smile breaks out across the fireman's face--like a who has suddenly found his purpose in life. He beams from to ear dousing the flames, while David runs to get anothe hose ...
(fading in)
... In honor and in recognition of your heroism ...
David stands at a podium receiving a commendation from "B Bob McGee (the man from the barbershop). He holds a large plaque up for public display, while "David's" whole famil beams in the background.
... And with great appreciation from the citizens of Pleasantville ... WIDER. A huge crowd is gathered on the town hall steps. There ar lots of balloons and bunting.
I am pleased to present You with this special commendation, from the Pleasantville Chamber of Commerce! He hands the plaque to David as the entire town bursts in APPLAUSE.
David walks away from the center of town looking down at plaque. He takes his sleeve and starts to rub off a smudg when a young woman comes up beside him.

Hi Bud ... WIDER. She is MARGARET ANNE HENDERSON, the prettiest girl in sch and one of the most popular. Margaret wears a frilly polk dot dress, that only accentuates a bombshell '50s figure. Nonetheless, she seems the image of girly innocence.
That was sure swell ...
Oh. Thanks, Margaret.
(smiling)
I baked you my oatmeal cookies.
(vaguely remembering an episode)
Oh, no ... You baked those for Whitey.
No. I baked them for you.
No. You baked them for Whitey.
(low and gutteral)
No. I baked them for you. All at once, Margaret grabs his arm and presses herself u against him. Her breasts shove up against his chest. Her mouth is inches away from his.
Um ... thanks. David can smell the weird combination of hot moist breath freshly baked cookies. He stares into her eyes for a mome unable to speak. Margaret flashes him a not-so Pleasantvi smile.
See ya. She turns and heads around the comer, while David just watches her dumbstruck.

David heads toward work with his apron and little paper h The BUDDY HOLLY music has given way to "hip" '50s JAZZ. D BRUBECK drifts out of the soda shop as David pauses for a moment, takes a bite of his oatmeal cookie, and heads ins SODA SHOP. The place has "morphed" even more. If it was a teenage hangout before, it has become almost a Bohemian coffee ho now. Brubeck's "TAKE FIVE" plays in the background while several patrons talk "intensely" in their booths. DOORWAY. David walks into the building and pauses. Next to him, on the boys from the basketball team plays along with the ja on a BONGO DRUM. There are several COFFEE cups on the tab Jennifer gets up quickly and comes over to him.
(in a whisper)
I had nothing to do with that fire.
(quietly)
It's okay.
Not directly anyhow ...
It's fine. David glances at the booth beside them and realizes that bongos have stopped playing. All the kids are staring up him, with a weird expression of awe.
(still under her breath)
Um ... They like wanna ask you a question ... I didn't know how to handle it. So ...
Sure. He crosses to the booth where Biff and two others look up him. It's like Elvis has entered the building.
How you doin?
Swell ... They keep on staring. Several glances are exchanged back forth like they're sharing a secret. Finally ...
How'd you know about the fire?
What?
How'd you know how to put it out and all? David hesitates, weighing his words.
Well--where I used to live ... That's just what firemen did. This sends a MURMUR through the shop. The boy leans forwa
And where's that?
(carefully)
Um ... Outside of Pleasantville. This sends a much LOUDER MURMUR rifling through the kids. It's like electricity. They glance excited at one another hush descends.
What's outside of Pleasantville?
Look it doesn't matter. It's not important.
What is it? David stops and looks out at the kids who are hanging on every word.
It's really not important.

What's outside of Pleasantville? REVERSE ANGLE. INCLUDING DOORWAY. Margaret Henderson (the girl with the cookies) stands in doorway staring at David. She hangs on his words with the same excitement as the others, it just means so much more
(hungry for knowledge)
C'mon. Tell us ... She stares right in his eyes. She's ten feet away but mig as well be touching him.
(slowly)
Well ... There are some places where the road doesn't go in a circle. There are some places where it keeps on going. There's an excited giggle. They lean forward.
(an exotic concept)
Keeps going ...
Well--it all just keeps going. Roads ... rivers ...
(from the back)
Like the "Mighty Mississippi".
... What? He moves forward extending a book. The cover reads: "THE ADVENTURES OF HUCKELBERRY FINN." David opens the first pa There is printing inside.
(quoting)
"It was big 'n brown 'n kept goin' an' goin' as far you could see."
(turning to Jennifer)
I thought the books were blank?
They were. He looks over at her.
(quickly)

Okay look, this like--wasn't my fault. They asked me what it was about and I like didn't remember 'cause we had it back in tenth grade, But I told them what I DID remember, and the next thing I knew the pages had filled in.
The pages filled in?
But like only up to the part about the raft, because I didn't read any farther. CLOSER. David flips through the book and sure enough only the fir chapter has print. The pages are blank after that.
Do you know how it ends?
(hesitating)
Well, yeah ... I do.
(breathless)
So how does it end? She has moved closer and is gazing at him from a couple o feet away. It's silent in the soda shop.

Well--see ... they're both running away--Huck and the slave ... And ... They go up the river ... But--in trying to get free they sort of see that they're free already. David looks immediately down to the blank pages of the bo that aren't blank anymore. Rows and rows of FRESH NEW TYP materialize in front of him. He turns to the back of the book, that is complete with a COLOR illustration.
(quietly)
Oh my God.
Wow!
Do you know this one? He shoves another book in front of David.
Hunh? (looks down at the book)
Oh yeah ... Well this is great. (beat)

See--Holden Caulfield is like this really lonely kid... EXT. PLEASANTVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARY. DAY. The CAMERA PANS down from the "PUBLIC LIBRARY' sign to fi the front door. A long line of kids waiting to check out their books stretches onto the sidewalk ... EXTREME WIDE SHOT. LIBRARY. FROM ACROSS THE STREET. Several men from the barbershop lean against the wall nex the spinning barber pole. They watch the spectacle for a moment or two, as teenager after teenager exits with an armful of books.
I don't know Phil. It's pretty strange.
I'll say it's strange. Gettin' stranger. Big Bob McGee nods and rubs his hands over his fresh hair
I mean goin' up to that lake all the time is one thing, but now they're going to a library! I mean what's next?

Oughtta be havin' an ice cream soda. That's where they oughtta be. WIDER STILL. From the shadows of the Town Hall, up the block, David watches the stream of kids emerge with their books. They cradle them in their hands like a piece of newfound treasure ... INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. George sits on the edge of his Barka Lounger, across the coffee table from "Big" Bob McGee. Even sitting down the is a looming presence. Besides owning the market, auto dealership, hardware store, and gas station, he also owns insurance agency where George works. George sweats into h collar.
Want some bridge mix?
Oh, no thanks ...
Betty's making some pineapple kabobs ...
I'm fine--but thank you. George nods as Bob takes a belt of his Martini and leans forward.
George, you're probably wondering why I asked if I could come over today ... George shrugs--then nods--then shrugs ...
I'm sure you've noticed the same things we all have--certain "changes" going on in the town. (beat)
You know what I mean by "changes"?
"Changes."
(nodding)
"Changes." (takes a belt of martini)
And it's not just the fire or big stuff like that. It's little things. (beat)
Did you hear about Bill Miller?
(concerned)
No. What?
Wife wants him to get one of those new beds.
One of those ... big beds? Bob nods.
Oh my gosh. What's he gonna to do?
I really don't know. (beat)
Ben Miller's son just quit his job as a boxboy at the market.
... How?

Said he didn't want to do it anymore. Just took off his apron in the middle of an order. Mrs. Thompson had her groceries spread all over the counter ... Took 'em four hours to sort the whole thing out.
Holy cow. Bob takes a belt of his drink ...
George, everyone likes you.
Oh well ...
No. They do. And it isn't just 'cause you're a great bowler ... They respect you ...
(heartfelt)
Thank you very much.
And it's important for them to see someone they respect, stand up for what's right. If you love a place, you can't sit around and watch this kind of thing happen to it.
No. Of course not.
(big patriarchal smile)
And that's why I want you to be on the Pleasantville Chamber of Commerce.
(stunned/ moved)
Oh my Gosh. I hardly know what to say.
(smiling)
Why don't you start by saying "yes," and then getting me one of those swell pineapple kabobs.
Oh sure ... You bet. (calling out)
Betty ... There is no answer.
(louder this time)
Still no answer.

head_text.subj: BETTY--BOB WANTS TO TRY ONE OF YOUR

text: George turns around to see David, standing on the landing listening to the entire conversation. Their eyes lock for moment ...

I'll get her. He moves quickly to the kitchen shutting the door behind INT. KITCHEN. David gets a couple of steps in and stops. He looks acros the room to see: REVERSE ANGLE. Betty standing at the kitchen sink, just staring out the window. Her back is to him. She grips the formica kitchen counter.
(approaching slowly)
Are you okay? She doesn't answer. David moves up to her and rests a han her shoulder.
Are you alright? Betty turns around to face him. HER FACE HAS TURNED

head_text.subj: COMPLETELY TO COLOR. THE EYES ARE GREEN. THE LIPS ARE RED

text: SHE HAS A NATURAL BLUSH IN HER CHEEKS. In fact the whole thing looks like a beautiful color portrait except for th tear stains on either side of her face.
(fighting tears)
What am I going to do? David moves closer and looks at her. Her lip is quivering
It's okay. It's alright.
(trembling)
I can't go out there. How can I go out there? She looks right up at David.
(quieter)
