Look at me ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. He stares at her for a second. Big green eyes full of fea and confusion. David pushes a reassuring smile.
Have you got any make up?
In my handbag. He crosses to the counter and grabs her purse. David sits Betty on a kitchen chair and fishes inside the handbag fo her compact. He finds it along with a wadded up Kleenex.

Okay--first we'll dry you out a little. He dabs at the tears, while she smiles at him in gratitud Then David opens the compact and takes out the large GRAY powder puff. CLOSER. It is a truly amazing sight. As David smears on the makeu she returns gradually to BLACK AND WHITE. The skin tones disappear. The flush of her cheeks goes. David takes out DARK GRAY lipstick, obliterating the bright red of her li REVERSE ANGLE. OVER BETTY'S SHOULDER. He works on her for a second or two, then takes a step ba All at once, David seems to wince: REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. BETTY'S FACE. The life is gone from her face. In an instant Betty has g from three dimensions to two. She stands in front of him, fictional version of herself all over again.
(off his reaction)
What? David shakes his head and forces a smile. He hands her th compact so she can examine herself. Betty holds it up to face, turning her head first right, then left.
(beat)
Does it look okay?
Looks just like it did.
And they won't be able to tell?
(even quieter)

No ... They won't be able to tell. Betty takes a deep breath and fluffs her hair. She grabs plate of Pineapple kabobs and heads for the door. Just be she goes in, she pauses, then plasters on a big wide "stewardess" smile ...
Wait.
(turning back)
What? He wants to say something, but doesn't. David shakes his head.
It's fine. She smiles again and balances the tray in front of her.
Thank you.
(sadly)
Sure. He watches as she opens the door, and marches in the room extending the little tray of hors d'oeuvres in front of her ...
Mr. Johnson is all alone in the shop, setting up the napk dispensers. He whistles BRUBECK'S "TAKE FIVE" when the sc door slams behind him. Mr. Johnson looks up with a start.
Oh, hi.
(entering)
Hi.
Aren't you a little early?
(quietly)

I brought you something ... From the library. CLOSER. FOLLOWING DAVID. He has a large book tucked under his arm that is easily t feet long. Mr. Johnson looks at him a little intrigued as David crosses to the counter.
It's an art book.
Oh my Gosh, Bud ...
Open it. Mr. Johnson reaches out and opens the cover. After a beat his eyes widen.

I just thought since you liked painting it might help to ... Mr. Johnson gasps. It's quiet, and subtle, but it's still gasp. David looks over at him but he's lost in the pages. HIS POV. (INSERT) ART BOOK ... Massacio's "Expulsion of Adam and Eve' leaps off the page vibrant, tortured color. The beauty of the garden is offs by their agony and their shame. HE TURNS THE PAGE ... Titian's "Venus to Utano". Soft, fleshy, in a rich golden light. She is utterly real and entirely nude. The folds o her flesh almost seem to glow ... Rembrandt's "Self Portrait." Dark reds, umbers, blacks an browns. He looks back at Mr. Johnson with pain and wisdom There's a brilliant light on his hair.

Mmmmgh ... Faintly, almost imperceptibly, the SOUND of a rich ARIA begins to UNDERSCORE THE IMAGES. It's so faint you can't sure you even hear it at all ... like you're hearing it w your eyes. He TURNS THE PAGES faster. Breugal's "Harvesters" ... Tum "Steam Train" ... Monet's "Cathedralo" ... Cezanne's "Oranges" ... Mr. Johnson shuts the book. WIDER. SODA SHOP. They sit like that for a beat.
It's beautiful, Bud ... He looks up at David, troubled.
What's wrong?
I'll never be able to do that.
Oh, well--you're just starting out. I mean, you can't do it ...
No, that's not it. Mr. Johnson shuts the book gently.
Where am I going to see colors like that? ANGLE. DAVID. What can he say. David looks over at Mr. Johnson who just smiles and shrugs.

Must be awfully lucky to see colors like that. I bet they don't even know how lucky they are. CLOSE UP. DAVID. He just stares for a second. EXT. MAIN STREET. LONG SHOT. DAY. Margaret walks up the center of Main Street toward the CA with her books pressed against her chest. She passes the drugstore, then the hardware store ... Far off in the distance, a young man comes racing out of the soda shop, pulling off his little paper hat as he goes. He comes run up behind her as fast as he can. CLOSER. He takes a deep breath and tries to quiet the panting.
Hi.
(turning/ lighting up)
Oh ... Hi.
(pause)
Look, I probably shouldn't be asking you this--not knowing you that well and all ... Margaret stops in the street and turns to him.
It's just that my folks are gonna stay home and they said I could use their car. (moment of truth/ abandoning his speech)
... You want to go out with me tonight? He wants to turn away but doesn't. David forces himself t stare at her and all of a sudden she beams. It's the whit pearliest smile in the world.
(breathless)
Sure ... Where would we go?
(swallows)
... Lover's Lane?

David comes flying around the corner in complete jubilati He vaults over a parking meter, swings around a lampost a leaps off the bumper of a parked car. David hi-fives into air at no one in particular and sails over Mr. Simpson's hedge almost decking him in the process.
(calling back)
Sorry ... FOLLOWING DAVID. He races across the street bobbing and weaving like an Al American fullback. David bounds up his front steps two at time flinging open the door. INT. PARKER HOUSE. FOYER.

"Oh when the Saints ... Go Marching in ..." He lets the door slam behind him as he takes off his apro and tosses it on the coat rack. David starts up the stair when he HEARS a MAN'S VOICE coming from the living room.
Bud ... He pauses a second and glances back.
David ... He peers into the living room. David goes a little grayer HIS POV. TELEVISION. Dick Van Dyke is looking back at him from the middle of t TV screen. He seems to have a bit of a stubble.
Hello there.
(wary)
(stage whisper)
Well c'mere, young fella. INT. LIVING ROOM. David crosses slowly over to the TV set.
(big smile)

You know I've been thinkin' ... I might have been a little "hasty" the other day when you asked to come home--just took me by such surprise, ya know--ha ha ... He gives a goony laugh. David just looks at him ...
So even though I can't make any promises, well--I figured if you asked me real nice--I might just be willing to talk about it again.
(quickly)
I can't.
What?
Talk about it. Right now, I mean. I got to ... um ... The look turns suddenly dark and ominous.
Bud--I thought you wanted to come home.
Oh ... I do. Yeah. It's just that I told my "dad" I'd clean out the rain gutters and Mr. Johnson wanted me to ... to change the tape in the register ...
(getting testy)
I'll be honest with you Bud. I'm getting sorta concerned about what I'm seeing in some of these re-runs ...
Re-runs?
Like when Margaret Henderson makes her cookies for Whitey. (losing it a little)
... Those aren't your cookies Bud.
Oh, I know they're not. But I mean-- they're just "cookies" after all ...
Excuse me?
Well they're not just cookies. I mean, they're great cookies ... Look, I'd love to get into this whole thing but I'm really running late. Why don't we hook up tomorrow?

Terrific. I'll talk to you then. He swttches off the TV sending Dick Van Dyke to electroni limbo. David stands in the middle of the living room, breathing hard ... INT. JENNIFER'S (MARY SUE'S) ROOM. She sits on the bed staring down at the front cover of a book. (It's an alien experience.) Jennifer is just about open it when she senses something and glances toward the door. REVERSE ANGLE. Bud is standing in the doorway just staring at her. He se to be out of breath.
What's wrong?
Nothing.
Nothing? He keeps breathing hard in the doorway. David holds the remote in his hand.
Listen ... He takes a couple of steps into the room and then suddenl stops.
You're reading?
(glancing at the book)
Yeah. Can't believe you started such a dorky fad. She holds up the cover.
D.H. Lawrence. You ever heard of him?
(amazed)
... Yeah.
Seemed kinda sexy. Look. I read 35 pages.
(still stunned)
That's great. He just stares at her for a second as his mind seems to drift ...
So what is it?
Well ... I just ... (out of the blue)
Can I ask you a question?
Sure.
Remember when you told me that Lisa Rosenberg liked me?
Yeah ...
Well--did she really like me or were you just making that up.
No. She really liked you.
You weren't playing a joke? She woulda gone out with me?
Gone out with you. She woulda like rearranged your tonsils.
Wow. He looks at her amazed--reliving the missed opportunity.
Can I ask you a question?
Yes.
How come I'm still in black and white?
(back to earth)
What?
Well I've had like ten times as much sex as these girls and I'm still like this. They have one hour in the back of a car and suddenly they're in technicolor.
Oh, I don't know. Maybe ... (thinks)
... it's not just the sex ...
(looking up quickly)

What? She stares at him wide-eyed like someone who has just hea their name called. Jennifer's eyes dart around like she's calculating a math problem. After a moment or two, her expression changes: a vague look of recognition.

No, it's not just the sex, is it? She glances down at her book. It's a big book. Jennifer t a deep breath and stares at the gray skin of her hand. Af a second or two, she looks back. David looks at her for a beat ...

David gets out of his "dad's" convertible, carrying a doz "gray" roses. He takes a deep breath and heads up her fro walk ... INT. CAR. NIGHT. LATER ... David sits behind the wheel of the borrowed car with Marg Henderson by his side. He concentrates hard on the road, holding the wheel at "10 and 2" as he steals a glance to right. HIS POV. MARGARET. It's not quite evening yet, and late afternoon light make her glow. Margaret smiles as she turns her face into the wind that swirls inside the convertible ... SHOT. DAVID. He studies her for a moment or two, then suddenly swerves avoid a parked car on his right ... WIDER. They pass a sign with a happy family on it that reads:

Main Street turns into a winding country road as they lea the town behind and head off into the woods. They wind through the dense woodland for a moment or two before a second sign appears, much like the first:
Sure enough, the town emerges in front of them again, completing the 4 dimensional circle. David looks confused
Um ... You gotta turn off Main Street.

Oh ... Right. He looks over at her and smiles. Margaret turns on the ra EXT. CAR. DUSK. SAM COOKE sings for them as David turns from Main Street a smaller unmarked lane. The car starts to rise up a smal hill, with Dogwood trees blooming on either side of the r It continues to climb up the narrow gravel lane toward th crest in the hill. David looks over at Margaret who takes deep breath shutting her eyes. He glances down at the sea between them ... HIS POV. CAR SEAT.

head_text.subj: THE ROSES THAT WERE GRAY HAVE SUDDENLY TURNED TO COLOR. T

text: sit next to him on the seat: a deep, rich RED ... INT. CAR. David looks up and out the windshield. The same thing see to be happening around them ... Many of the Dogwoods have started to turn PINK. Not all of them, but at least fifty percent of the petals have "bloomed" in some weird false spring. The road twists and turns on its way to the top, they finally reach a crest in the hill.
Wow. THEIR POV. LOVERS LANE. There, sitting in front of them, is a whole world gone Technicolor: THE LAKE IS BLUER THAN BLUE. THE WEEPING WIL IS GREENER THAN GREEN. THE DOGWOOD PETALS (all "turned" n

head_text.subj: SWIRL IN THE WIND LIKE SOME STRANGE PINK SNOWSTORM. A LON
LINE OF PASTEL CARS STRETCHES OUT ALONG THE SHORE.

text: (over the car radios)

"Cupid, draw back your bow ..." SHOT. CAR. Slowly, David rolls the convertible forward. Many of the have left their cars and sit down along the grassy bank b the edge of the water. A few of them have books open. It almost looks "Athenian." INT. CAR. David looks at the whole scene for a moment then suddenly cocks his head to the side.
What's that smell? Margaret looks at him and smiles. She leans well out of t convertible, and plucks a Gardenia from a bush that is blooming beside the car.

Aren't these great? David takes the flower, then puts it up to his nose. He t a long deep breath then all at once, his posture seems to relax. As the fragrance enters his body his eyes drift li some strange narcotic is washing over him. David lowers t flower ... EXT. MAIN STREET. DUSK. Betty is walking down Main Street with a shopping bag on either hand. From a block away, she looks like any other homemaker in Pleasantville. You don't even notice the gra make-up. CLOSER. FOLLOWING BETTY. She nods to Mrs. Filmore in the bakery and smiles at Don the Post Office. Betty is just about to turn on Elm Stree when she glances up, and suddenly stops. HER POV. ACROSS THE STREET. There, in the middle of the block, sits Mr. Johnson's sod shop. The whole scene is still black and white, except fo the large CUBIST PAINTING THAT FILLS MR. JOHNSON'S WINDOW is rendered in bright PINKS, YELLOWS AND ORANGES, and loo like a Braque or a Picasso except for the unusual subject matter. Upon closer examination you see that all the sphe and cones add up to an avante garde snow scene, with a Cu Santa hovering over the roof tops. SHOT. BETTY. She stares at it, mesmerized for a moment, then starts to wander across the street. It's late afternoon and the business district is empty. Betty crosses in the middle o the block, staring straight ahead. INT. SODA SHOP. The door opens and she sticks her head inside. Most of th place is dark except for one streak of sunlight shining through the window near the back of the store. Betty glan around. The little bell JINGLES as she enters.

We're closed right now ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. He sits in front of a small easel near the back, staring board which doubles as a canvas. Mr. Johnson glances over shoulder and recognizes Betty in the doorway.
Oh, hi ...
(turning to leave)
I'm sorry ...
No, no ... Come on in. REVERSE ANGLE. He gets up from his stool and crosses toward the door, st holding the palette in his hand. Betty stares at the "Cub Christmas" in the window.
I just thought ... It's beautiful.
Thanks. Their eyes lock for a second. Sort of a clutzy silence. M Johnson motions toward his easel.
I was just trying to do one of these "still lifes." He sighs and looks behind him. Next to the easel is a bow GRAY FRUIT.
Having kind of a tough time.
I think it looks nice.
Well ... (shrugs)
Here's what it's s'posed to look like. He leads her over to the table and points down at the art book. It's open to a Cezanne that nearly burns off the pa
Oh my ... CLOSER. They are standing almost on top of each other gazing down the book. Neither one of them moves. Betty almost disappe into the pictures--drawn by a strange new world.
Here. Look at this. He turns to Kandinsky--a massive swirl of color. The imag nearly electric.
(breathless)
Where'd you get this?
Bud brought it to me.
Bud?

Here's my favorite. INSERT. BOOK. He turns the page near the back to one of Picasso's "Weep Women." The woman is rendered in pink and red and green. head is a large sphere, laying "peacefully" on her own shoulder.
What do you think? She doesn't answer ...
Isn't it great how she's resting like that?
(faintly)
She's crying. WIDER. Mr. Johnson looks down at the painting.
What?
She's crying.
No she's not.

Yes she is. He looks up at her ... REVERSE ANGLE. A single tear is running down Betty's cheek. She senses i and reaches up to wipe it quickly away, but instead of ju wiping the tear, she takes off a huge swath of GRAY MAKE- A long strip of PINK FLESH is revealed underneath. ANGLE. MR. JOHNSON. He stares up at her in amazement. ANGLE. BETTY. She senses something and glances down at her hand. Her fingertips are covered in GRAY MAKE-UP. Betty turns and b for the door. WIDER.
(following her)
Wait ...
I've got to go ...
It's alright. He stops her near the door and she turns her face toward wall. Mr. Johnson touches her shoulder.
It's alright. Let me see.
(shame)
No ... He reaches up and gently touches her chin. Mr. Johnson mo around to glimpse the other side of her cheek.
It's beautiful. CLOSER ... She freezes like that for a moment, then slowly, haltingl turns toward him. THE COLOR of her real flesh is revealed underneath. Betty stands there exposed.
(a whisper)
... It's beautiful. She swallows, not sure what to do. Betty glances down.

You shouldn't cover that up. Mr. Johnson reaches over to the little napkin dispenser o the counter and pulls one out. He leans forward and dabs the tears beneath Betty's eyes. Then slowly, gently, he starts to wipe the makeup off her cheek. CLOSER STILL ... She recoils a bit, tensing up, then just looks at him. Mr Johnson is gazing at her "true color" with wonder and acceptance. She hesitates for an instant, then seems to m a decision. Betty slowly turns her face to the side, expo her flesh all the way down to the neck. Mr. Johnson conti to wipe off the make up in larger and larger strokes as t beautiful pink flesh begins to emerge ...

She lies on her bed, reading the same book she was browsi earlier. Jennifer seems strangely engrossed as she flips pages, lying on her stomach, scouring every word. After a moment or two she gets restless and shifts position, lift the book. The cover is plainly visible: "LADY CHATTERLY'S

She doesn't have enough light so Jennifer rises from the and crosses to "her" desk. She sits in the chair and flat the book in front of her. Jennifer is deep into the plot doesn't even look up as she flicks on the desk lamp. She could almost be studying algebra as she sits upright at t little desk. DIFFERENT ANGLE. She flips the page and peers more intently. Her hair is bothering her so she pulls it back and knots it in a pony tail. After a little while her eyes begin to get more tir and she looks up and blinks a couple of times. Jennifer notices something across the desk. REVERSE ANGLE. A pair of Mary Sue's glasses are neatly folded in front o her. Jennifer reaches out, puts them on her head, glances back down at the print.
(impressed)

Hunh. She can see much clearer now. Jennifer folds her hands in front of her and doesn't even realize that she has mimick the PHOTOGRAPH OF MARY SUE THAT SITS BESIDE HER IN A SILV FRAME. The face is the same, but that's to be expected. S the pony tail, the glasses, the posture and the studious on her face. Jennifer turns the page engrossed in her nov when there is a loud TAP on the window. She rises from the desk and pulls back the curtain. Jenni slides open the window. EXT. PARKER HOUSE. Biff stands on the front lawn tossing pebbles at the wind
Mary Sue--C'mon ...
(leaning out the window)
What are you doing?
(jiggling in anticipation)
It's six-thirty ...
So.
We were gonna ... You know ... He jiggles some more.
Oh. (remembering)
I can't.
Why not? She glances down at her book.
I'm busy.
(surprised)

With what? INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She hesitates for a second then glances back at the desk. own image in the silver frame stares back at her. The hai pulled back in a pony tail. The glasses sit on the front her nose.
(turning to Biff)
I'm studying. She thinks about it for a moment, then suddenly smiles. B stands dumbfounded on the sidewalk as Jennifer reaches up quietly closes the window ...

David and Margaret sit on the edge of the grass, looking across the water. Even in the moonlight, the COLORS are vivid. David still clutches the gardenia in his hand, tak a long hit like an Opium addict.
(inhaling)
Mmmmgh.
Do they have those ... Where you come from?
Yeah ... I guess. (beat)
I don't know.

You don't know? Margaret laughs like that isn't even possible. She shifts the grass hiking her skirt up above the knee. It reveals long tan leg beneath it. David watches as she kicks off h shoes, rubbing her feet through the long cool grass.
So what's it like?
What?
(a whisper)
Out there. She clings onto the words like they could transport her b themselves. David thinks for a moment.
Oh. don't know ... It's different. She leans forward.
How?
Well it's louder ... And scarier I guess ... And ... and a lot more dangerous ...
Sounds fantastic. You know some kids came up here the other night to go swimming--took off all their clothes. She giggles. David looks at her in amazement.
Do they have an Ocean? I've heard about the ocean.
Yeah.
What's that like?
Well it's big. And it's blue ... (as if realizing it for the first time)
... It's really really blue.
Mmmm. (beat)

Boy. It's hot up here. Suddenly and without warning Margaret unbuttons her cardi sweater. She slips it off, arching her back like the figurehead of a ship and David just stares at her breasts She wears a light cotton blouse and even in the moonlight forms a translucent silhouette ... She lays the sweater across the grass and leans back on it.
You want some berries?
Hunh? She unfolds a handkerchief revealing a handful of berries REDS AND BLUES AND PURPLES.
I picked them myself. They grow wild up here. (eating one)
Mmm. So sweet.
(looking at them)
They just grow like that?
(looking straight up)

Oh yeah. There's a lot of stuff. Currants and strawberries ... Here. I'll show you. She hops up and scampers across the grassy bank, kicking heels behind her. Margaret reaches a tree in the distance reaches toward an upper limb, stretching out her body lik piece of statuary. She picks a piece of fruit and scamper back toward him, hiking up her skirt as she goes ...

Here. CLOSER. Margaret sticks out her hand, offering him a BRIGHT RED APPLE. It's brilliant and shiny and glistens in the moonlight. ANGLE. DAVID. He hesitates just looking at it. Margaret speaks in a whisper.

Go on. Try it. HIS POV. She is lying on her stomach now, and behind the outstretc apple he can see an ample view of her cleavage. Margaret smiling at him as the apple shines in the foreground. Dav reaches out and takes it. WIDER. DAVID AND MARGARET. For this instant, they seem alone in the garden. He looks down at it, then glances over at Margaret. David hesitate for a split second then takes a bite of the apple ...

George heads home with his briefcase in hand whistling a happy tune. He smiles at Mr. Simpson and swings the attac case as he turns and heads up his front walk. INT. FOYER. George opens the door and sets the briefcase by the stair like he always does. He hangs his hat on the hatrack, his coat on the coatrack, and beams as he hollers his nightly greeting:
Honey--I'm home. There is no response. He looks a little perplexed but smi as he calls out again:
Honey--I'm home ... There is more silence. George looks around a little confu when there is a BOOMING CLAP OF THUNDER ...

Betty sits in a comer of the shop, next to the gray bowl fruit. She holds her head to the side, sitting gracefully with her chin in the air. Mr. Johnson sits behind his eas painting her portrait from a few feet away. Betty looks radiant with no trace of the makeup, the warm PINK OF HER FLESH TONES lit softly by a bare forty watt bulb ... CLOSER. She looks over at Mr. Johnson when they hear the BOOMING OF THUNDER. Each of them freezes. There is ANOTHER, LOUDE BOOM ... ANGLE. WINDOW. The "Cubist Snowscene" lights up brightly, illuminated by sudden flash of lightning behind it. Betty leaps up from chair and crosses to the window looking out.
(frightened)
What is that?

I don't know. Betty looks back at Mr. Johnson and suddenly sees the painting. She flinches for a second. Her eyes go wide. REVERSE ANGLE. INCLUDING THE PAINTING. It is Cubist (like the rest of his recent work) but that isn't the shocking part. Even though she sits in front of fully clothed, Mr. Johnson has painted a beautiful, sensu nude. Betty just stares at the canvas, stunned to see her revealed like that. The COLORS are all hot pinks and oran and yellows--like some Fauvist celebration of summertime. There is another even LOUDER PEEL OF THUNDER. WIDER. BETTY AND MR. JOHNSON. She looks over at Mr. Johnson and he glances down. After moment or two he looks back at her, but she doesn't turn run. Betty just stares at him, then without even realizin it, moves slightly closer.

David and Margaret are locked in a deep passionate kiss. first they don't separate when they hear the BOOMING CLAP THUNDER. It is only when they hear the SECOND ONE and the RAIN starts to fall, that Margaret pulls back and looks u the sky.
What is that? ANGLE. DAVID. He is still in an amorous daze and doesn't even feel the increasing rain. It starts to pound harder and Margaret l to him in terror.
What's going on?
Rain.
Real rain?
Yeah ... You don't have rain either? She looks at him frightened. David smiles.
Right. Of course you don't ... He puts his jacket around her and starts to lead her up t grassy slope. A dozen other couples go scurrying up the b looking in terror at the water falling from the sky.
What do we do?
(reaching the car)
We'll just put up the top. He goes fishing around the boot of the car, looking for t catch to release it. David leans into the back seat fishi around as the rain starts to pound harder.
What top? He looks back at her. No top either. David smiles, drench in rain and puts his arm around Margaret who is starting shiver.

It's fine. Come on. He leads her back to a thicket of bushes where several of kids are clustered together. They look at one another, terrified, as they huddle for shelter beneath the ledge o overhanging rock.
It's alright. There's nothing to be afraid of. They look a little reassured and Margaret looks up at him positively adoringly. She clings to his shoulder as the s howls a few feet away ...
She stands at the window looking out at the driving rain. Jennifer still holds the D.H. Lawrence book in her hand. There is a huge flash of lightning and another clap of thunder.

Cool ... She flops back down on the bed and continues to read ... PARKER LIVING ROOM. George wanders through the empty and darkened house completely perplexed and utterly disoriented. He looks ar for his family, but all he can find are the darkened room and the sound of the driving storm.
(a little frightened/ a little petulant)
Honey, I'm home ... He still can't find her and he crosses into the DINING RO The lights are dark there as well and he looks around confused.
(baffled)
Where's my dinner? He sniffs a couple of times but there are no familiar coo smells. George flings open the door to the kitchen but th empty as well. KITCHEN. He crosses into the darkness ...
Where's my dinner ... INT. FOYER. George comes reeling out of the kitchen into the foyer. H slams his shin on the coatrack but keeps on going ...
(insistent)

Where's my DINNER ... EXT. HOUSE. It's really blowing now. The rain is coming down in heavy sheets, being swirled and driven by the wind. The front d opens and George wanders out onto the front porch, still dressed in his shirtsleeves.
Where's my DINNER! ON GEORGE. He stumbles down the front walk in a state of complete confusion. The rain pounds against his body and within seconds his shirt is soaked through to the skin.
(over the storm)
A tree limb crashes to the ground but he keeps stumbling through the torrent. George reels down Elm Street screami skyward in the distance.

He turns on Main Street and goes reeling past the insuran agency where he works. George howls into the wind and he passes the hardware store, the gas station, the bakery .. Finally he pauses outside the barbershop. It's empty as w with the spinning barber pole being buffeted by the rain. George lowers his arms and just stares into the darkened shop. His voice grows quieter bewildered and shivering ..
(plaintively)

Where's my dinner? He wraps his arms around himself and shivers on the sidew INT. BOWLING ALLEY. NIGHT. The regular occupants of the barber shop spread out acros three lanes. Each wears a Pleasantville bowling shirt, sponsored by one of Big Bob's businesses. The NOISE from the crashing pins is deafening and there aren't any windows so the storm has gone unnoticed ... ANGLE. BIG BOB. He picks up a 7-10 split and claps his hands in delight. starts to cross back to the scorer's table when he looks and suddenly stops. REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. George is standing in the doorway to the bowling alley co and shivering. His shirt is soaked through to the skin. H hair is drenched and dripping.
What happened? He doesn't answer. George clutches his body and keeps shivering. WIDER. The men stop bowling and rush to George's side. He blinks couple of times, still soaked to the bone.
Are you alright? (looking at him)
What is it?
(faintly)
Rain.
(beat)
Real rain? George nods. Bob rushes to the glass door of the bowling alley and sees the driving storm. A huge fork of lightnin lights up the sky.
Oh my God ... He turns back to George.
... We had no idea. Burt was rolling a 250 and ... (beat)
Are you alright? George shivers and Bobs leads him over to one of the benc and guides him into the seat ...
What happened?
(still shivering)

Well, I ... I came home like I always do, And I came in the front door. And I took off my coat. And I put down my briefcase and I said "Honey. I'm home." ANGLE. MEN. They all nod in recognition. ANGLE. GEORGE.
... Only no one was there. A MURMUR goes through the men.
So I went into the kitchen and I yelled it again. "Honey--I'm home." But there was no one there either. No wife. No lights. No dinner. They all GASP.
So I went to the oven--you know-- because I thought maybe she had made me one of those "TV dinners ..." The men nod and lean forward. George shakes his head.
But she hadn't. She was gone. A LOUDER MURMUR moves through the crowd. George lowers hi head and just shakes it from side to side. Big Bob moves and puts a hand on his shoulder.
(gently/ the patriarch)
... It's gonna be fine George. George looks up at him helplessly. Bob pats him reassurin on the back.
What do we do Bob?

Well--we'll be safe for now--thank goodness we're in a bowling alley-- but if George here doesn't get his dinner, any one of us could be next. It could be you Gus, or you Burt, or even you Phil ... They murmur again. Bob gathers a little steam.
(like a WWII movie)

... That's real rain out there gentlemen. This isn't some little "virus" that's going to "clear up on it's own." There's something happening to our town and I think we can all see where it comes from. They nod in agreement.
We're gonna need a town meeting. Phil, how fast can you turn around a leaflet in your print shop?
Couple of hours.

Gus, why don't you get a bunch of kids from the basketball team to help you put them up on lamposts and tree trunks ... Gus nods. Big Bob turns to George and smiles. It's a warm patriarchal smile. He claps a hand on George's shoulder.
(soothingly)

And the first thing you're gonna do is get a cup of hot cocoa and a nice dry bowling shirt. INT. SODA SHOP. NIGHT. The rain still pounds out the window. Betty and Mr. Johns are huddled in one of the booths watching the deluge thro Mr. Johnson's snow scene in the window. Betty is in soft radiant color now. Almost the whole frame seems to glow pink ...
You can't go out there.
But I really should get home.

But you can't go out there. There is another fork of lightning and a booming peel of THUNDER. Betty sighs. She's past struggling. Betty shuts eyes for a moment and listens to the rain pounding on the roof.
Sounds nice ... Once you get used to it.
(listening)
Yeah. It does. There is another flash and a loud BOOM. Betty smiles this time.
Like a drum.
Yeah. (thinks)

Or like sprinklers in the summer ... Betty smiles. They both listen for a moment and the fear seems to fade a little. The RAIN POUNDS harder on the roo Betty nestles down in the booth, a little closer to Mr. Johnson. They just sit there listening for a moment or tw Betty starts to smile ... EXT. LOVER'S LANE. David huddles with Margaret under the rocky ledge as she nestles against him with her head on his shoulder. INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She lies on her bed, still reading the book, the spitting image of Mary Sue. Her hair is up in a bun now. The glass have slipped down her nose. There is another fork of lightning and the LOUDEST THUNDER CLAP of all. Jennifer smiles slightly and pulls Mary Sue's afghan over her shoulders as she fluffs the pillow and turns the page.

Drops of moisture cling to the petals as it GLEAMS BRILLI RED IN THE MORNING SUN ... AERIAL SHOT. PLEASANTVILLE. The rain is gone now. The town glistens in the sunlight complete with a huge RAINBOW arching across the sky. Literally all the COLORS IN THE RAINBOW shine against the black and white of the town. It looks like a greeting car INT. SODA SHOP. Betty and Mr. Johnson are asleep in the booth, lying in e other's arms. Sunlight streams in through the window, war Mr. Johnson's face which has now turned to color. He open his eyes and looks outside ...
(seeing the rainbow)

Oh my Gosh ... EXT. LOVER'S LANE. Birds are chirping. David and Margaret also lie asleep in each other's arms, beneath the shelter of the rocky overh Margaret lifts up and sees the rainbow. She has turned to color as well ...
(awed)

Oh my God ... INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She has passed out on her bed with her book on her chest. Jennifer's hair is still tied in a bun and she still wear Mary Sue's glasses, but her face has returned to its rosy pink hue. She blinks open her eyes, feeling the sunlight, looks out the window.
(looking at the rainbow)

Oh my God ... INT. BOWLING ALLEY. The men are all passed out across the various lanes and scoring tables. It looks like a YMCA shelter. After a mom or two Big Bob yawns, and stretches, and glances out the glass doorway. He sees the rainbow and freezes in shock.
(horrified)
Oh my GOD!

David comes gliding up Maple Street in the sunshine with huge smile on his face. He has that special grin and fara look that a boy only knows once in his life. Perplexingly is still in black and white. Bud turns on Elm Street and starts heading for his house when he glances up and sudde freezes. HIS POV. TREE TRUNK. There, tacked to the bark, is a hastily scrawled public notice:
He looks up at it for a moment. INT. PARKER KITCHEN. DUSK. George and Betty stand face to face in their suburban kitchen. He is black and white. She is in full color.
I told you where I was.
All night?
I got caught in the storm. You were gone all night too.
(the ultimate defense)
I was in a bowling-alley. Betty turns--glances out the window.
(sudden smile)
Look. Let's just forget about it. Let's just go to the meeting and ...
I told you, George. I'm not going.
(bigger smile)
Sure you are.
No I'm not. She turns to face him. George flinches slightly.
Look at me George. That meeting's not for me. Look at my face.
It's fine. You'll put on some make up and ...
I don't want to put on some make up ... George's eyes widen. It's a watershed moment.
(protesting)
It goes away ... It'll go away.
(gently)
I don't want it to go away. He suddenly squares back his shoulders and puffs out his chest.
(the '50s patriarch)
Okay--now you listen to me ... (beat)
You're gonna come to this meeting and you're gonna put on this make up, and you're gonna come home at six o'clock every night and have dinner ready on this table.
(softly)
No I'm not sweetie. His expression leaves as quickly as it came. Betty moves closer to him.
(half whisper)

... There's a meatloaf in the fridge. You just put it in the oven and turn this little knob up to three-fifty. If you put the pie in forty minutes later, it'll be hot in time for dessert. George's eyes widen.
I made a couple of lunches for you and put them in brown paper bags ... (much quieter)
I'm gonna go now.
Where are you gonna go?
I'm gonna go now. She turns and starts out the kitchen door when George cal after her.
Betty, don't go out there like that! They'll see you! (beat)
They'll SEE you! And she closes the door behind her.

Betty, come back here! EXT. TOWN HALL. NIGHT. Dozens of black and white citizens stream in through the front door. SHOT. OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE STREET. Several "transformed" teenagers stare at the spectacle wi their FLESH COLORED SKIN AND BRIGHT BLUE EYES. They seem hang back in the shadows. INT. TOWN HALL. Big Bob stands at the podium beneath a permanent banner t reads "PLEASANTVILLE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE." As the only legally constituted body in Pleasantville, it is a natura place for a town meeting. There is nothing bright and che however. The floor lamps in each comer cast huge, looming shadows up the walls. The light at the podium bathes Big Bob's face in a blinding splash of light. The whole thing evokes some weird twisted image from German Expressionism like they are about to go look for Frankenstein. It is gr than gray. CLOSER. PODIUM. Big Bob stands at a lectern with a Rotary insignia on the front. He speaks calmly but compellingly to a hundred men women who hang on his every word. Bob holds a BRIGHT YELL GRAPEFRUIT.

This was found over in Dave Murphy's trash can. There were four of them like this ... There is a murmur from the crowd ... CLOSE UP. GEORGE. He sits up on the stage in an honored position right behi Bob. George wears a shiny new ROTARY PIN in his lapel, as full-fledged member of the Chamber of Commerce. He sits s and upright with the sense of safety and reassurance that shiny new pin can give you. SHOT. BOB. He holds up a pair of BRIGHT RED BOXER SHORTS.
Jane Davidson found these in her son's laundry basket. There is a LOUDER MURMUR. The crowd shifts in their seats Bob points behind him to a BRIGHT GREEN lawn chair.
This is from Mary Petersen's front porch. She found one last week. There were two more this morning ... The MURMUR starts to grow ...

David and Margaret stand beneath the big Elm tree outside Margaret's house: a statue of two young lovers. They wrap their arms around each other in a classic silhouette. The meeting across town seems a million miles away. After a moment or two, David reaches behind the tree and pulls ou beautifully wrapped gift. It is three feet long with a br RED bow.
(softly)
I got you something. Margaret's eyes widen. She beams at him, then tears off t wrapping paper revealing a great big umbrella ... a real umbrella. She looks up at him thrilled.
It's beautiful. Where'd you get it?
It was a prop for the school play ... She looks down and giggles.
Can I open it?

Sure ... Margaret gives him a quick kiss then opens the umbrella. puts it back on her shoulder and turns a series of pirouettes--like her own kind of rain dance. Margaret poi her face up to the sky as if she is being showered by a summer storm. All at once a pair of HEADLIGHTS round the corner. WIDER. David grabs the umbrella and closes it quickly. Margaret looks to the street as the convertible slows to a crawl a two TEENAGE BOYS pull up beside them. They are clean cut BLACK AND WHITE faces ...
Hello Bud ...
(clipped)
Hello Whitey. They smile at each other for no good reason. It's scary a arrogant.
(more pointed)
Hello Margaret.
Hello Whitey ...
(loud)
Hey Bud, how come you're not at the town meeting right now?
(curt)
No reason. (pause/ firing back)
How come you're not?
Oh. We're s'posed to go out and let everybody know about it. See. He points to an ARMBAND that has some sort of Chamber of Commerce seal on it. Whitey leans out of the car and leers ...

No reason hunh ... See I thought maybe it was cause you were too busy entertaining your colored girlfriend. Margaret literally flinches. The boys share a PEEL OF LAUGHTER AND SNORT AT EACH OTHER. David puts an arm aroun her and pulls her close.
Why don't you guys just get the hell out of here.
Oh, okay, Bud. We'll do that. He guns the engine as if to leave, then pauses and turns toward Margaret.
(leering more)

You know Margaret, you can come over and bake those Oatmeal cookies for me anytime you want to. They share another CHORTLE as Whitey guns the car and pee out with a SCREECH. Margaret's lip starts to quiver and D holds her tighter ...
It's fine ... It doesn't mean anything. She nods, groping for reassurance ...
The chamber of commerce meeting is still in full swing. Various citizens are now on their feet, screaming from th audience.
Ed McFadden's got a blue front door.
It's always been blue!
Not that blue!
There's a big tree turning orange in Joe Baker's front yard! SHOT. GEORGE. He still sits behind Bob with the same stoic expression o his face. George fingers the little pin in his lapel ...
People, people ... I think we all know what's going on here. SHOT. BOB. Bob lifts his hands in the air. The crowd quiets down a b

Obviously certain "changes" have been happening. Up until now, things in Pleasantville have always been-- well ... "Pleasant." And, recently, certain things have become ... "Un-Pleasant." Now it seems to me the first thing we have to do is to separate out the things that are pleasant, from the things that are "Un-Pleasant." There is a loud murmur and nod of agreement ...
George, why don't you and Burt take the lead on this. Why don't you put together kind of an "Un-Pleasant" Activities Committee ...

Mr. Johnson has scrubbed the snow scene from the window a stares with his palette at a blank pane of glass. There i knock at the door ... WIDER. Mr. Johnson puts down the paints and crosses to open it. Betty is standing in the doorway clutching her purse and "Lady Samsonite Weekender" bag. She stares up into his ey

Burt Campbell opens up the hardware store like he does ev morning, only today there is a slight difference. He swin open the door, puts out the rakes and shovels, then sets newly handwritten sign clearly in the front window:

As the businesses are opened on Main Street, more and mor "NO COLOREDS" signs appear in the windows: next to the donuts ... by fishing poles ... beside the stationery supplies ... Everything else looks frighteningly the same

Joey Anderson, the local paper boy, is finishing his morn rounds. He reaches in his bag and tosses left toward the bakery. Then he throws right toward the post office. Then turns left toward the soda shop, does a double take and s into a trash can ... WIDER. SODA SHOP. Where Mr. Johnson had once painted his cubist snow scene, there is a brand new painting that isn't cubist at all. A NUDE version of Betty graces the shop window--painted in curving sensual brush strokes. Joey stops his bike and ju stares in amazement. He gets up and rides away as fast as possibly can ...

David is in a happy daze, wandering up Main Street and doesn't even notice the crowd gathered outside Mr. Johnso soda shop. After a moment or two, he glances up and sees window ... CLOSER. DAVID. His eyes go wide. The murmur of the crowd grows louder as stray derisive comments rise above the noise. David glanc from the nude in window to the growing angry mob ... MAIN STREET. DAY. David goes tearing through the business district looking any sign of his "mother." He glances in the flower shop . toward the green grocer ... David is just about to turn o Elm Street when a booming voice seems to come from the sky ...
Bud ... David stops and looks to his right. There, in the window the Philco TV store, are twenty screens of various sizes displaying the image of Dick Van Dyke.
I want a word with you ...
(scared)
Oh--well ...
(BOOMING)
The sound reverberates like God Himself. David ducks insi the store, slamming the door behind him. INT. STORE. Fifty Dick Van Dyke's stare at him from every TV in the store. The effect is smothering.
(still pretty loud)
What the hell do you think you're doing! David glances around, not sure where to look.
(terrified)
What do you mean?
What do I MEAN! (beat)
You think this is a toy? You think it's your own little goddamn coloring book ...
Look--it just sort of "happened" ...
A deluge doesn't just "happen." Bolts of lightning don't just "happen" ... (louder)
You burned down an ELM tree for Christ's sake ...
I had nothing to do with that.
Oh. I'm sorry--refresh my memory. What episode does the orgy happen in, again?
Look ...
It was a gift Bud. It was so special. You liked these things as much as I did, remember: Warm smells in the family kitchen? A smile from a stranger? You know how rare that is?
(beat/ quietly)
... Only if they mean it. Dick Van Dyke looks at him for a beat, then goes "red" in face.
(finding courage)
I didn't do anything wrong.

Oh no? Let me show you something! SHOT. TV SCREEN. All at once a box appears in the upper right hand comer o the screen containing the image of David and Margaret at Lover's Lane. The VIDEOTAPE rolls forward as she extends BRIGHT RED APPLE. David hesitates, then takes it, then pu it to his mouth and takes a bite.
The image of David biting the apple PLAYS BACKWARDS AND FORWARDS like some football instant replay ...

head_text.subj: YOU DON'T DESERVE TO LIVE IN THIS

text: David just stares at the repeated images of Dick Van Dyke the TV screens.
(quickly)
Where's the remote control I gave you?
Why?
Because you're coming home. I'm gonna put this place back the way it was.
No you're not.
(gathering strength)
I'm sorry ... I can't let you do that.
(nuts)
He lunges toward the screen and slams his hand against th "barrier."
(terrified)
I'm going to leave now.
You're not going anywhere. You're gonna get that remote and you're gonna come home and we're gonna make everybody HAPPY AGAIN!!! Dick Van Dyke looks at him stunned as David turns and lea the shop.

Don't make me get rough with you! I can get awfully fucking rough! ELM STREET. DAY. David sprints down the tree lined street toward his house The leaves on some of the trees are starting to turn GREE even this far into town. David vaults over Mr. Simpson's hedge and goes tearing up his front walk. INT. FOYER. The door flies open and he rushes in, breathless. David glances around the house to make sure that it is empty. H crosses into the living room. INT. LIVING ROOM. David rushes to the TV and grabs the remote. He looks dow it, glances at the television, then bolts for the front d MAIN STREET. DAY. David moves quickly down Main Street looking for a place stash the remote. He pauses in front of the Pleasantville Travel Agency. It has posters in the window depicting var destinations in and around Pleasantville (the place doesn see much business). David bends down to stash the remote drain pipe near the entrance when he hears VOICES from up street. WIDER. David turns to see a small crowd up near the end of Main Street. He sticks the remote in the drain pipe and rises his feet as the voices get louder. DIFFERENT ANGLE. The crowd is moving toward him. A woman walks in front of group of young men who circle around her, taunting and harassing her. A moment later David can make out the face BETTY clutches her handbag to her chest while the crowd circles her like a pack of dogs. CLOSER. BETTY. The ROSY HUE of her face stands out in stark relief to th black and white faces around her. Betty holds her head hi with dignity (and fear) while the ugly epithets overlap o another "Oooh--let's see the rest of you ... Let's see wh under that nice blue dress ... Bet she's even pinker than picture ..." One of the boys yanks at Betty's skirt and s quickens her pace. Just at that moment the boy is shoved the ground ... WIDER. David shields his "mother" as he shoves one of the boys i the dirt. The kid gets up but David punches him hard in t side of the jaw and the rest of them just stare. (Violenc as new as anything else and it seems to freeze the moment David steps in front of his "mother" with both fists clenched.
(as scared as she is)
Come on! He plants his back foot primed for action. The crowd of b and white thugs just stares at it.
They look at him warily. The boy reaches up and feels the side of his mouth where a trickle of RED BLOOD is running down his chin. He looks at his finger in horror and start backing away.
Get out of here! They back away further and David takes a threatening step The boys turn and run as he turns back to face his "mothe
David moves up to her gently.
Are you alright? She nods, still clutching her purse to her chest. David reaches out and touches her cheek when suddenly her eyes wide.
(off her look)

What? CLOSER. STILL OVER DAVID'S SHOULDER. Betty reaches into her purse and pulls out her compact. S opens it, and holds it up to David, showing him the refle image of his own face. AT LAST HE HAS TURNED TO COLOR. REVERSE ANGLE. DAVID. He holds the mirror staring at his own reflection. The courage which transformed him only seems to grow. They lo at each other, both in color now, when David puts a gentl arm around her shoulder.
(quietly)
Come on. He begins to lead her up toward the corner.

A larger crowd of hooligans has now gathered around the n painting of Betty in the window. The jeers and cat calls even louder. The "closed" sign still sits in the doorway. After a beat or two, a HUGE BRICK SHATTERS THE GLASS ... WIDER. A big CHEER goes up from the crowd. Drunk on adrenalin, t fever builds and ANOTHER BRICK SMASHES THE WINDOW. In an instant, Mr. Johnson's "canvas" is totally destroyed. The CHEERING grows louder ... Almost by osmosis, the crowd rushes the building together The door is kicked in and they stream into the place. Soo all that can be heard is the weird SOUND OF LAUGHTER AND BROKEN GLASS. INT. SODA SHOP. It is an orgy of destruction. Stools are hurled--tables ripped out. The cash register is turned over. Two boys ki in the front of the juke box ... EXT. MAIN ST. DAY. David and Betty round the corner to find the Soda Shop be destroyed. They stand at the far side of the intersection watching the carnage as the crowd continues to run amok. After a moment or two, there are some more HOOTS as MARGA comes running toward them with the front of her blouse ri open.
Oh my God. He takes her in his arms and Margaret starts to sob. Davi strokes her hair.

Are you alright? Are you okay? She nods. Margaret catches her breath for a moment or two then glances down to her side ... WIDER. She is clutching the umbrella in her left hand. The thing been ripped to shreds. The spines are broken and the fabr is torn. Margaret stares at the thing with a combination confusion and shame. David goes white with rage and looks toward the mob.
(taking his arm)
No. Let's get out of here.

They all ride in George's convertible up the twisting tur road. It has turned completely PINK with the dogwood peta David winds up the trail, in the fading light, looking fo refuge. He clutches the wheel tight.

We should be okay up here. DIFFERENT ANGLE. THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD. The car twists and turns up the narrow dirt road. After a moment, Lover's Lane reveals itself. It is lush and green like before only this time, there is one major difference phalanx of BLACK AND WHITE THUGS have created a roadblock the foreground. WIDER. David jams on his breaks when he sees the barrier. It is weird incongruous image: the black and white roadblock in front with the vibrant colors of the pond and willow behi like some perfect dream you can never get to. The thugs h turned their cars sideways and dragged several huge logs across the road. They hold axe-handles in their hands.
(a whisper)

We better go. EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. Darkness has fallen and the streetlamps have come on. Som debris is scattered around the street and distant sounds the mob still fill the air. David rolls back into town wi the headlights off. CLOSER. CAR.
Where are they?

I'm not sure. They head down Main St. and turn the comer on Walnut. All once, a weird ORANGE LIGHT bathes the car ... REVERSE ANGLE. THEIR POV. A BONFIRE has been lit in the middle of the street betwee library and the barber shop. Twenty to thirty people are gathered around it still whooping and hollering as the br ORANGE FLAMES shoot into the air. ANGLE. CAR. David pulls over by the curb, and their eyes go wide ... REVERSE ANGLE. From closer up, it becomes clear what they're burning. Hu piles of library books have been dumped onto the sidewalk waiting their turn on the pyre. There is a strange celebr atmosphere as they chuck book after book on the flames, w the glee of a teenager tossing a firecracker. David sees something and bolts from the car ...

Oh my God. ANGLE. SIDE OF THE BONFIRE. Jennifer is locked in some strange wrestling match with B He clutches a book over her head while she tugs at his wr trying to stop him from throwing it on the fire ...
Don't! Just let go.
It's better, Mary Sue.
I said, NO! (yanking it)

... I've read like one book in my whole life and I'll be damned if I let you throw it on that fire ... Jennifer wrestles with him for a couple of seconds and th suddenly kicks Biff in the groin. He doubles over in agon when Jennifer snatches the book and bolts in the other direction. DIFFERENT ANGLE. STREET. She sprints up the street and is just passing the barber when a hand reaches out and grabs her. Jennifer starts to scream but David puts a hand to her mouth.
(a whisper)
It's okay. It's me.

The crowd has moved on and all that is left is the dark wreckage of the soda shop. Several stools lie out in the street and shards of brightly painted glass are scattered around the sidewalk. It is eerily quiet. WIDER. David, Betty and Margaret sit silently in the car, across street with the lights off. He unlatches the door handle gets out slowly. The rest of them follow him into the emp street as they move silently toward the soda shop, like s platoon on patrol. REVERSE ANGLE. As they get closer, more of the wreckage comes into view. a booth ... a soda spigot ... After a moment or two Jenni looks up and gasps. CLOSER. Several teenagers step out of the shadows. They have scra faces and ripped clothing--the signs. Most are dazed and OF THEM ARE IN COLOR. After a second or two, more appear: Mary Jane ... Lisa Anne ... The boy who was reading Huck Finn... ANGLE. DAVID. The kids turn to him as if he has some kind of answer. Of course he doesn't. The sounds of the Mob still carry thro the air from somewhere off in the distance.

Let's go inside. INT. SODA SHOP. The place is just sad. All the remnants of what they had strewn around the floor, The jukebox is turned over. The stools are ripped out of the floor. Betty looks over at t corner where he painted her ... The easel is smashed to b ANGLE. BETTY. She brings a knuckle to her lip and David puts an arm aro her and draws her close. After a moment or two they HEAR weird SCRAPING sound.
Hello? The SCRAPING SOUND stops. They all look to the open door after a second or two, Mr. Johnson appears holding a broo dustpan.
Just thought I'd try to tidy it up a bit. Betty runs across and throws her arms around him. The teenagers watch as she holds him tight.
It's okay. Once we sweep it up it'll be alright again ... Betty stifles a sob as he strokes her hair. No one says anything while they just embrace for a moment. Finally ..

Well he's right. Come on. Let's turn these booths back up. "Mary Sue", why don't you help me slide this in front of the door. We'll be okay in here. They respond to the tone of leadership. One by one the ki start to pitch in, sifting their way through the wreckage Jennifer and David slide a barricade in front of the door the kids try to put their shop back together.
Big Bob stands at the podium addressing a packed house. T atmosphere is odd: somewhere between a bake-off and a lynching. People sit in the aisles and in the window sill Bob points his finger.
This is not the answer people. The crowd quiets a bit. He leans over the lectern.

No matter how upset we may get, or how frustrated we may be, we're not gonna solve our problems out in the street. It's just the wrong way to do it. We have to have a "Code of Conduct" we can all agree to live by. His tone grows softer--more concerned ...
Now, I asked George and Burt here to sketch out some ideas-and I think they've done a terrific job. (beat/ scans the crowd)
If we all agree on these then we can take a vote and I think we'll start to move in the right direction. ANGLE. CROWD. They murmur and nod ...
(reading from the CODE OF CONDUCT")

"ONE: All public disruption and acts of vandalism are to cease immediately." EXT. BONFIRE. NIGHT. It is still ablaze with books. As Bob continues to READ i VOICE OVER, a firetruck comes screeching up to the curb. SHOT. FIRETRUCK. The same fireman who learned to use the hose before pulls several yards of it from the back of the truck. He can ba contain his excitement as he gets to open the valve and extinguish the raging bonfire ...

"TWO: All citizens of Pleasantville are to treat one another in a courteous and "pleasant" manner ..." SERIES OF SHOTS. LAMPPOSTS. The CODE OF CONDUCT is nailed to lampposts and tree trunk rapid succession. It is plastered on walls and in shop windows ... SODA SHOP. Debris is still strewn around the street. A dim light emanates from inside. INT. SODA SHOP. It looks like a scene from the French Revolution. Ten to fifteen kids huddle behind the barricade while David read the code of conduct out loud by flashlight.
"Courteous and Pleasant manner." That doesn't sound too bad. David just looks at her then continues.
(reading from THE CODE)
"THREE: The area commonly known as Lover's Lane as well as the Pleasantville Public Library shall be closed until further notice." This sends a murmur amongst the kids.

"FOUR: The only permissible recorded music shall be the following: Pat Boone, Johnny Mathis, Perry Como, Jack Jones, The marches of John Phillips Souza or the Star Spangled Banner. In no event shall any music be tolerated that is not of a temperate or "pleasant" nature."
(overlapping)
"Oh my gosh ... No ..." David holds up his hand.
"FIVE: There shall be no public sale of umbrellas or preparation for inclement weather of any kind." Various glances dart back and forth between them. David continues.
"SIX: No bedframe or mattress may be sold measuring more than 38 inches wide." (pause)

"SEVEN: The only permissible exterior paint colors shall be BLACK, WHITE or GRAY, despite the recent availability of certain alternatives." David looks over at Mr. Johnson who just winces slightly. Betty clutches his hand.
"EIGHT: All elementary and high school curriculums shall teach the "non-changist" view of history-- emphasizing "continuity" over "alteration." (David pauses)

Wow. David lowers the paper. DIFFERENT ANGLE. It is SILENT in the soda shop. Everyone sits motionless f moment or two, letting the decree sink in. David just sta down at the piece of paper in his hand with a weird kind sadness. Off in the corner, however, one of the boys has been fidd with the jukebox and hasn't paid any attention to what wa being read. All of a sudden, his voice rings from the cor
Hey. This thing works. He hits a button and BUDDY HOLLY's voice fills the soda s RAVE ON blares at almost top volume recalling a more fest time.
Well all the things that you say and do Make me want to be with you-oo-oo ...
(suddenly/ in a panic)
Turn that off! The boy looks back at her.
(shrieking)

You're not allowed to do that now! He flinches and pulls the plug from the wall. The jukebox winds down with a groan as the electricity drains out of David looks at the kids then suddenly speaks in a calm cl tone.

Sure you are. He walks across the soda shop and plugs it back in. The k watch spellbound at this personal display of defiance. WIDER SHOT. SODA SHOP. Buddy Holly's voice fills the Soda Shop but it has a sudd different meaning. All the kids listen spellbound, as if an anthem, while the Rock and Roll lives up to its rebell reputation.

The little things that you say and do Make we want to be with you-oo-oo ... RAVE ON! It's a crazy feeling ... RAVE ON! It's got me reelin' ... Jennifer looks over at her brother with pride. Betty puts arm around Mr. Johnson, feeling a little stronger--a litt safer ... The kids seem to relax a bit, and even if they don't feel totally reassured, at least they don't feel ashamed. Twenty "colored" faces listen as Buddy Holly tells them R ON. David stands beside the jukebox like a captain at the helm of his ship ... EXT. STREET. LATER ... He steps out over the debris and looks both directions. D motions toward the shop and a moment later the kids emerg The disturbance seems to have died down and the street is silent although strewn with debris. David turns to the ki
(whisper)
Stick together till you get off Main Street. They nod and head off down the block. David just watches silently from the wreckage of the soda shop ...

The Fire Department is cleaning up the charred remains of bonfire ... INT. SODA SHOP. LATER ... Betty is asleep in one of the booths. Jennifer sleeps bes her on the floor. David and Margaret sleep next to them i another booth with Margaret curled up against his chest. David opens his eyes. REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. Mr. Johnson is standing in the middle of the shop, starin the large piece of plywood where his window used to be. H just gazes at the thing as if he could look through it. There's a faraway look in his eye. SHOT. DAVID. He rises carefully from the booth, without waking Margare David crosses over to Mr. Johnson and speaks in a whisper
It's okay. We'll get you a new one.
(softly)

I don't know what I'd do if I couldn't paint anymore Bud. I just don't know what I'd do ... CLOSE UP. DAVID. He just nods. David glances down at the table next to him picks up one of the brightly painted shards of glass and looks at it. It's orange and pink and yellow. David think for a second.
Maybe I have an idea.

The same paper boy who rode into the trash can, peddles d Main Street tossing his papers toward the curb. He throws right toward the post office, then left toward the hardwa store, then right toward the bakery, then finally looks u CLOSER. This time the boy slams into a lamp post. He tumbles off bike and stares straight ahead in disbelief ... HIS POV. TOWN HALL. Two men sleep at the base of the wall next to a clutter o paint cans. Above them, however, is painted A VIVID ALMOS UTOPIAN MURAL OF THE TOWN OF PLEASANTVILLE in LIVING COLO Instead of being drab, the place literally gleams with li The post office turns out to be a RICH RED BRICK. The sky shines in vibrant BLUE. It is a rendering of what the tow could look like. David and Mr. Johnson sleep soundly next their own signatures. David opens his eyes and sees the paperboy ... ANGLE. PAPER BOY. He turns around and rides away as fast as he can.

A huge crowd has gathered. There is a loud buzz in the ai David and Mr. Johnson stand side by side in front of thei work like they're presenting and guarding it at the same time. REVERSE ANGLE. CROWD. Most of the faces are black and white. A few near the bac are in color. Big Bob moves through the back of the crowd hurriedly buttoning his shirt. The buzz grows and the peo part as he heads toward the front of the pack ... ANGLE. FRONT OF CROWD. When Bob emerges from the crowd, Mr. Johnson flinches slightly. David just looks him in the eye and tries to fi as much courage as he can. "Big" Bob looks up at the colo rendering of his town with absolute horror. His eye scans green trees, the bright yellow gas station, the puffy pin clouds on the horizon.
(bellowing)
Did you do this?
(quietly but clearly)
Yes I did. Bob grabs a copy of the Code of Conduct and waves it at h
Do you know that it's illegal?
(thinks)
Yes I do. Bob looks dumbfounded. He tries to process the whole thin but just looks more confused. Bob runs his hand through h hair, shaking his head.

Because anybody should be able to paint in whatever color they want. ANGLE. BACK OF CROWD. Betty stands beside Margaret and Jennifer watching the spectacle. There are tears in her eyes and a great deal o love. Jennifer smiles with pride at her brother ... SHOT. BOB.
You're not allowed to do this! I could arrest you for this.
Still doesn't make it right. There is some clapping from the back of the crowd. Bob's widen. His face goes flushed (darker gray). A vein bulges his neck. He turns to the police chief.
Dan! Arrest them!
(quietly)
Um ... I don't know how to do that, Bob.
What do you mean!?
Well, I never had to do it before.
You put handcuffs on them and you take them to the police station.
(thinks)
Oh. guess I could do that, then.
(suddenly stronger)

C'mere, Dan. I'll help you. David walks toward the police chief and sticks his hands A louder murmur moves through the crowd as David actually helps him fasten on the cuffs. Mr. Johnson comes over to them and the murmur starts to grow ...

A bright full moon stands out against a jet black sky ... EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. A group of "colored" kids hangs out on Main Street near t police station. They gaze off into the distance at the ba window of a jail cell. It is elevated half a story above street. Everything is black and white except for the warm YELLOW LIGHT, that glows through the bars. They know in a glance who's inside. INT. JAIL CELL. NIGHT. David sits on his bunk staring at the ceiling. The place never been used so there is still plastic wrapping on all sheets and pillow cases. He can't help smiling. INT. DIFFERENT JAIL CELL. WAY OFF DOWN THE HALL ... Mr. Johnson crouches on his bunk, ignoring his food. He clutches a rusty nail and scratches at the plaster wall i true "inmate" fashion. REVERSE ANGLE. WALL. Rather than scratching the days or even the hours, Mr. Johnson has carved a huge pastoral landscape into the wal complete with lush forest and a running brook. He looks a his work and smiles. SHOT. POLICE CHIEF. He approaches David's cell from the other direction and knocks gently on the bars. David turns around.

There's someone to see you Bud. DAVID. David sits upright on his bunk trying to think who it cou be. After a moment or two, a strange look of understandin crosses his face. He HEARS the sound of a KEY TURNING IN LOCK. David looks up at the doorway and smiles.
I thought it might be you. REVERSE ANGLE. DICK VAN DYKE. He stands in the doorway, still dressed in his TV repairm outfit. FOR THE FIRST TIME, HE IS COMPLETELY IN BLACK AND WHITE.
Hope you're proud of yourself.
I am actually ... Glad to see you've finally shown your true colors. Dick Van Dyke gives a tight smile and shuts the door of t cell behind him.
Okay, let's cut the shit and get right to it. Where's that remote control?
Why?
Because you're coming home.
(smiles)
Why don't you just take me back without it?
Oh. You're a smart little bastard aren't you? (tightly)
It's kind of like a restricted ticket. You gotta leave the same way you came. David just looks at him. He smiles, confidently. Leans ba on the bunk ...
So ... I guess as long as I'm here, all sorts of things could happen to this place. We could have pink lawns and blue trees ...
Just gimme the damn remote!
I'm sorry. I can't do that. Dick Van Dyke takes a deep breath. He glances toward the barred window.
I don't know what went wrong. You answered every question. You knew every detail. The senior Prom ... McIntire's Department Store. We had all the same warm memories: Sock hops. The Church Social ...
They weren't my memories. (beat)
I borrowed them. It's no good when you borrow them. Dick Van Dyke's eyes go wide and he literally starts to tremble.
(containing his rage)
How long do you think you've been here?
(warily)
I don't know ... Three, four weeks.
Much less than that. (checks his watch)
An hour and a half. David looks at him uneasily. Dick Van Dyke flashes a broa nasty smile.

See--and this is really great-- the show was on for what--half an hour a week? So that means for every week that goes by in Pleasantville, only half an hour goes by in the real world. The smile gets bigger. Dick Van Dyke moves closer to him.
Now Buddy, you're going on trial tomorrow. And if they find you guilty, you're gonna be stuck here forever. Well, not forever--lemme think ... (calculates)
Five year sentence ... Carry the three ... That comes out to ... sixteen and a half centuries, and that's rounding down.
I'm going on trial tomorrow?
This is TV pal. They don't fool around. David is rocked but tries not to show it.
(stoicly)
There's worse places.
Oh sure. For the first hundred years. Then it starts to get a little monotonous. (beat)

Sleep well. He taps on the bars for Dan who opens the lock and lets h out. The door CLANGS shut as the two of them disappear do the hall. The minute they are gone, the stoicism falls. D looks around his cell, truly afraid. CLOSER. He stares at the tiny cot ... The plain light bulb in the ceiling ... The single pillow with the plastic covering i ... Forever is starting to look like a long time. David crosses to the small window and looks out. HIS POV. OUT THE WINDOW. Across the town square he can see the side of the Town Ha complete with the newly painted mural. The "Utopian" view Pleasantville is just as he left it with one notable exception: The edges of painting are starting to turn bac BLACK AND WHITE.

It is bathed in sunlight. Dozens of people stream through front door for the first trial in Pleasantville's history There is a weird carnival atmosphere in the air. INT. TOWN HALL. DAY. The place has been transformed from the Chamber of Commer meeting hall to a small town courtroom, complete with pew and ceiling fans. The only carry over from its previous configuration is the huge CHAMBER OF COMMERCE banner drap across the back wall. ANGLE. BENCH. At the center of the courtroom where the podium used to b a large, elevated judge's bench with a Rotary insignia on front. Big Bob sits six or seven feet above the proceedin finally living up to his name. The whole thing is a stran combination of Franz Kafka and "Inherit the Wind." Big Bo bangs the gavel ... CLOSER. The undertone begins to quiet down. All of the faces in t pews are Black and White. There is a "colored" section in back for standing room only. ANGLE. JURORS BOX. George is seated in the front row of the jury, despite hi relationship to one of the defendants. He is dressed impeccably with his Rotary Pin still gleaming on his lape After a moment or two he sneaks a glance toward the back the room ... ANGLE. BETTY. She stands in the back with the rest of the "colored" fac Betty cranes her head to catch a glimpse of David or Mr. Johnson. All at once, a hush goes through the crowd. ANGLE. DOORWAY. It swings open and David and Mr. Johnson are led in weari handcuffs. Dan, the Police Chief (now ballif), shows them a table in the center of the room directly facing Big Bob There is no lawyer present. There is also no prosecutor. ANGLE. DAVID. He glances around a little confused. (Weird courtroom.) B Bob bangs the gavel.

Bud Parker and William Johnson, you have been charged with desecration of a public building and the intentional use of prohibited paint colors in violation of the Pleasantville Code of Conduct and laws of common decency. Do you admit that on the night of May 1, you did consciously and willfully apply the following FORBIDDEN colors to the Pleasantville Town Hall: (beat)
Red, Pink, Vermillion, Puce, Chartreuse, Umber, Blue, Aqua, Ox Blood, Green, Peach, Crimson, Yellow, Olive and Magenta.
Um ... Yes I do. Where's our lawyer?

We prefer to keep these proceedings as "pleasant" as possible. I don't think a lawyer will be necessary. There is a murmur and a great deal of nodding amongst the black and white faces. Big Bob smiles to himself then proceeds.
Do you further admit that this was done surreptitiously and under the cover of darkness?
Well--it was dark out ...
Good. Do you further admit that this unnatural depiction occurred in full public view where it was accessible to, and in plain sight of, minor children?
It was accessible to everyone.
Very well. Let the record show that the defendants have answered in the affirmative to all the charges. He looks directly at them for the first time.
Do you have anything to say in your defense? SHOT. DEFENSE TABLE. Mr. Johnson just looks at David, confused and terrified.

I didn`t mean to hurt anybody. I just have to paint ... I need to. He gropes for something else to say, but what else is the David glances over and sees him sit slowly back in his se David rises from his chair.
I think I've got something to say.
Very well ... David looks out over the audience. After a moment or two, looks back at Big Bob.

I think I know why you're doing this. I mean, I understand why you're doing this. I used to feel the same way. I used to want this place to stay just the way it was. I never wanted it to change ... There is a loud MURMUR. Big Bob bangs the gavel.
(he smiles slightly)

But nothing stays the same. You get things, and you lose things, and that's the good part and the bad part--but you can't have a good part without a bad part. He turns and sees his mother in the balcony. They lock ey for a moment. David smiles slightly and continues.
It's like the basketball team.
(leaning forward)
The basketball team?
Sure. Everybody's upset because they're not winning anymore--but just think how it would feel if all of a sudden they do win. There's a murmur in the gallery.
Wouldn't it feel better than when they used to win all the time? There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob looks concerned.
See, I know you want it to stay "Pleasant" but there are so many things that are so much better: like Silly ... or Sexy ... or Dangerous ... or Wild ... or Brief ... (beat)
And every one of those things is in you all the time if you just have the guts to look for them. (pointing to the "colored" section)
Look at those faces back there. They're no different than you are. They just happened to see something inside themselves that you don't want to ...
Okay--that's enough!
I thought I was allowed to defend myself.
You're not allowed to lie.
I'm not lying ... Here I'll show you. He turns suddenly toward the jury box.
Mr. Simpson ...
Yes.
What color is that hedge of yours?
Green.
No, not that hedge. The other one.
The other one?

The one in your mind. The one that you see on a bright cold morning. The one that you see when you walk in front of your house and you just stand there and stare. Mr. Simpson suddenly looks far away. He gets a kind of dr look in his eye.
What color is that hedge? CLOSE UP. MR. SIMPSON.

head_text.subj: SUDDENLY AND BEFORE OUR EYES, MR. SIMPSON TURNS TO LIVING

text: COLOR. A huge MURMUR moves through the courtroom. Bob ban the gavel.
I said, that's enough!
"No ... Let him finish ... Go on ..." Big Bob lifts the gavel and is about to bang it when Davi suddenly turns toward George.
Alright. Dad ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob just looks at him froze while David confronts his "father." George straightens up
(solemn)
Yes Bud.
(beat)
Don't you miss her? CLOSE UP. GEORGE. He looks at him stunned. Big Bob bangs the gavel but nobo listens. George just stares at him like he got shot.

I mean, of course you do, but it isn't just the cooking or the cleaning that you miss--it's something else, isn't it ... George swallows. The UNDERTONE in the room starts to grow he glances toward the back of the room.
(softer whisper)
Maybe you can't even describe it. Maybe you only know it when it's gone. Maybe it's like there's a whole piece of you that's missing too. (shrugs)
You might even call it "love."
(BANGING the gavel loudly)
Okay, that's IT!!!
(motioning toward the back)

Now don't you think she looks just as pretty in color? Don't you think she looks just as pretty as she did the day you met her? Slowly, almost imperceptibly George nods. A single tear r down his cheek. As it traces the side of his face it leav long trail of COLOR behind it.
Don't you wish you could tell her that? He nods again and it all comes out. Betty smiles at him through her tears. Even Mr. Johnson smiles as well.
(POUNDING the gavel)
Why am I out of order?

head_text.subj: BECAUSE I WILL NOT ALLOW YOU TO
TURN THIS COURTROOM INTO A CIRCUS

text: Well I don't think it's a circus. And I don't think they do either. David motions behind him to the black and white section. There are now ten to fifteen "colored" faces.

head_text.subj: THIS BEHAVIOR WILL STOP AT ONCE.

text: But see that's just the point. It can't stop at once. Because it's in you. And you can't stop something that's in you.
(tightly)
It's not in ME.
Oh sure it is.
No it isn't. He crosses to the bench looking right up at Big Bob. He l over the bench and gets right up in his face.
(smug whisper)
What do you want to do to me right now? Big Bob starts to tremble. He shakes with rage as David m closer.

C'mon. Everyone's turning colors. Kids are making out in the street. No one's getting their dinner-- hell, you could have a flood any minute ... Pretty soon you could have the women going off to work while the men stayed home and cooked ...
That's not going to happen!
But it could happen.

No it couldn't! Big Bob looks at David and starts to tremble. It starts around the base of his neck, spreads quickly up the rest his head. After a moment or two, Big Bob has gone complet RED IN THE FACE. WIDER. A gasp goes through the courtroom. David looks at him and just smiles. The crowd reaction turns almost to a ROAR as Bob turns and catches his reflection in the window. CLOSE UP. BIG BOB. He sees the ruddy image staring back at him, then looks d at his hands. They have gone completely RED as well. Big freezes for an instant then bolts from the bench in panic flees the room--flinging open the doors to the courtroom. ANGLE. DOORWAY. As Big Bob flees, he reveals an amazing sight: the Town Square GLISTENS IN LIVING COLOR. The huge lawn is a rich green. The sky is a dense opaque blue. Dozens of spectato bolt from their seats and rush to the doorway as the crow moves outside.

All the birds are really chirping. Red Brick, Yellow cars Green hats ... The barber pole in front of Gus' has final turned to red, white and blue--he can't help smiling. Dav walks out into the sunlight and stares in wonder at his creation. The whole town is washed in joy. WIDER. Margaret comes up and throws her arms around him. They me in a rich passionate kiss (in direct defiance of the code conduct). Several people around them actually clap, like spectators at a wedding. Jennifer moves up next to them a looks at her brother making out.
Uch ... I am like gonna hurl ... David turns and looks at her. Both of them laugh. David throws his arms around his sister as more and more people stream out of the courtroom into the sunlight ...
David and Jennifer stand together on the edge of town. Sh clutches a valise in her hand. He holds the remote contro
Are you sure?
I told you. I'm like positive.
This thing works. We could go home right now.

I'm not ready yet. I gotta do this for a little while. WIDER. They stand on the edge of town (which finally has an edge A large sign says: "Springfield 12 Miles" and for the fir time, the end of Main Street is no longer the beginning. Jennifer is dressed in Mary Sue's clothes with a little b of style thrown in. Rich fields of wheat spread out in th distance.
Besides. You think there's like a chance I'm gonna get into college back there?
(thinks ...)
Honestly ... no. They both smile.
You got the admissions letter.
Right here.
And you're sure about this?
I've done the slut thing, David. It's really kinda old. David nods.
I'll come back and check on you in a month. Jennifer nods and gives him a hug. She holds on tight for couple of seconds.

You're like the coolest brother in the world. David smiles. Never been called cool before. They suddenl hear the SOUND of a motor and look to their left. A huge Greyhound bus lumbers up the highway, pulling to a halt a the sign. The doors open beckoning her in. Jennifer smile her brother, then turns toward the door ... EXT. MARGARETS HOUSE. DAY. She clutches her umbrella at her side. David holds a bag oatmeal cookies. Each one clings on to the other one's clothing. Their faces are inches apart.
You're gonna forget about me.
No I won't. I swear. Margaret nods. She looks at him for a moment then wraps h arms around his neck. They meet in a long, rich, wet, sof kiss. The umbrella falls to the ground ...
(a whisper)
I like calling you David.
I like it too. INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. David stands in front of the television with Mr. Johnson his side. He holds the remote control in his hand. Mr. Johnson seems pretty amazed at the whole idea.
Well how do you know it won't go back to the way it was?
You're gonna keep painting aren't you? Mr. Johnson nods.
Well ... He nods again and thinks about it. They smile at each oth one last time.
(remembering something)
Oh. (reaching into his pocket)

I've got something for you. He pulls out a folded piece of paper. Mr. Johnson extends to David who unfolds it and instantly smiles. INSERT. PAPER. It is a small painted replica of their mural in the same vibrant colors. Everything is scaled perfectly, exactly l the one on the wall. SHOT. DAVID.
It's beautiful.
Just a little--You know. David looks up at him and smiles. All at once he glances toward the door. WIDER. Betty is standing there holding a brown paper bag. A swea is draped over her arm.
(extending the bag)
I made you these for the trip. They're marshmallow rice squares.
Thanks. I thought you weren't gonna ...
(painful/ quieter)
I had to say goodbye. She looks up at David and their eyes lock. Betty hands hi the bag.
There's a meatloaf sandwich in there too. Don't go skipping dinner just 'cause you're not here anymore.
I won't.
(voice quivering)
And ... wear this on the trip in case it gets cold.
(nodding)
... It's a pretty short trip. She nods as well. Betty puts the sweater around his shoul anyway and fusses with the collar for a second or two. Th she throws her arms around his neck.
I'm so proud of you, Bud.
Thanks ... I love you.
I love you too. She clings on tight for a second or two then lets go. Bet flicks away a tear and draws a deep breath.
Well ... She steps back and looks at him. David glances down at th remote.
You better stand back a little. Betty and Mr. Johnson cross toward the comer of the room. David points the remote at the TV ...

All the ersatz Spanish houses stretch out toward infinity WESTEC security patrol cruises by them at a crawl. A seco or two later, all the sprinklers turn on in uniform synchronization. INT. DAVID'S LIVING ROOM. He stands in the middle of the living room looking at his new/old surroundings. Everything is the same as it was. T black onyx coffee table. The clean burbur rug. The big sc TV in its sleek black cabinet. David looks at it and smil The place is inadvertantly in black and white. CLOSER. He reaches forward and turns on the TV (by hand) flipping around the dial. Jerry Springer is berating a prostitute Tony Robbins hawks self-improvement in an infomercial ... Court TV is doing an O.J. recap. David unfolds Mr. Johnso sketch and glances down at it. He smiles to himself. A different kind of nostalgia ...
